title: State v. Smith
description: Affirms the circuit court's grant of a new trial because the minor victim was coached by a relative during his testimony.
text:
State v. Smith


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Appellant,
v.
Arthur Franklin Smith, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4202
Heard December 4, 2006 â€“ Filed February 5, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor I. McDuffie Stone, III, of Beaufort, for Appellant.
Acting Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.: Â Arthur Franklin Smith was convicted of first degree criminal sexual conduct with a minor and sentenced to twenty years imprisonment.Â  The trial judge granted Smithâ€™s new trial motion on the ground he was denied a fair trial, because the testimony of the victim, John Doe,[1] was corrupted and his free will potentially overridden by the coaching of Doeâ€™s aunt, Cynthia, during his testimony.Â  The State appeals the grant of a new trial.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Smith, Doe, and the rest of their immediate family moved to Bluffton from New York in the summer of 1998.Â  After the move to South Carolina, Smith and Doeâ€™s mother were divorced.Â  Doe was removed from his motherâ€™s care after he was discovered engaging in sexual behavior with the son of his motherâ€™s boyfriend.Â  Doe underwent counseling, entered a sexual offender addiction program and was placed in Cynthiaâ€™s custody. Â 
Cynthia testified that she and Doeâ€™s teachers were alarmed by Doeâ€™s unusual behavior.Â  Doe would urinate on the walls of his bathroom and bedroom and wipe his feces on the walls at school.Â  Doe also exhibited violent behavior at home and became very difficult to control at school.Â  Concerned by Doeâ€™s behavior, Cynthia enrolled him in counseling.Â  Doe eventually revealed Smithâ€™s molestation of him during one of the counseling sessions.Â  
Doe testified that Smith abused him when Doe was six or seven years old during visits to Smithâ€™s home.Â  Smith warned Doe that if he revealed the abuse to anyone, Smith would â€œkill [Doe] or break [Doeâ€™s] bones.â€Â  Doe described appalling sexual abuse and testified that such abuse occurred more than three times.Â  
After Doe finished testifying, Smith, through his counsel, requested that the trial court remove Cynthia from the courtroom while Roe testified.Â  Counsel stated: Â â€œI didnâ€™t object after [Cynthia] testified to [her] be[ing] in the courtroom.Â  But it was apparent during [Doe]â€™s testimony that there were motions and mouth movement and things going back and forth between the witness and [Cynthia] and that was reported to me by individuals in the courtroom.â€Â  Cynthia then voluntarily left the courtroom.Â  
Doeâ€™s brother, Richard Roe, who was fifteen at the time of trial, testified in an in camera Lyle[2] hearing that he suffered similar abuse from Smith when he was six or seven years old.Â  The abuse allegedly occurred several times when the family lived in New York, but stopped once the family moved to South Carolina.Â  
After Roe finished testifying, Smith moved for a mistrial on the ground that Cynthia coached Doe during his testimony.Â  The trial court denied the motion on the grounds that Smithâ€™s counsel knew or should have known of the coaching and did not make a contemporaneous objection so that corrective action could be taken.Â  Smith renewed the motion for a mistrial at the conclusion of the Stateâ€™s case, and the trial court again denied the motion.Â  
The trial court sent the case to the jury, which found Smith guilty.Â  After sentencing, the issue of the extent of the auntâ€™s coaching of Doe during his testimony was revisited.Â  
After hearing testimony from court officials who witnessed Cynthiaâ€™s alleged coaching of Doe, the trial court granted Smithâ€™s motion for a new trial.Â  In doing so, the trial court concluded that: Â 1) Cynthia used body language and other non-verbal signals in an attempt to communicate with Doe; 2) this communication may have overridden Doeâ€™s free will; and 3) this behavior and the potential for corruption of Doeâ€™s testimony denied Smith his right to a fair trial.Â  The State appeals.
DISCUSSION
Appealability
Our case law makes clear that in order for the State to appeal the grant of a motion for a new trial, the error of the trial judge in granting the motion must be predicated on an error of law.Â  See State v. DesChamps, 126 S.C. 416, 418, 120 S.E. 491, 492 (1923) (â€œ[W]here the grant of a new trial in a criminal cause is predicated wholly upon error of law, we think an appeal by the State will lie.â€); See also State v. Johnson, 363 S.C. 184, 189, 610 S.E.2d 305, 307 (Ct. App. 2005) (â€œThe State may appeal the grant of a new trial when it appears it is based â€˜wholly upon an error of law.â€™â€) (quoting State v. Dasher 278 S.C. 395, 400, 297 S.E.2d 414, 417 (1982)).Â  The State contends that there is no evidence in the record to support the trial judgeâ€™s finding that Cynthiaâ€™s coaching actually affected Doeâ€™s testimony resulting in prejudice to Smith.Â  They rely on Doeâ€™s testimony during re-direct examination that his responses were his own.[3]Â  At oral argument, the State asserted that this complete lack of evidence made the judgeâ€™s grant of a new trial rise to the level of an abuse of discretion and error of law.Â  However, the trial judge appears to have based his decision to grant a new trial on the factual findings that Cynthia made the impermissible gestures to Doe during his testimony and that there was a likelihood he was improperly influenced.Â  While there are lingering questions regarding its appealability, this issue presents at least a mixed question of law and fact, and we elect to address it on the merits. 
Law/Analysis
Examining the issue on the merits, we must first consider our scope of review.Â  â€œ[T]he grant or refusal of a new trial is within the discretion of the trial judge and will not be disturbed on appeal absent a clear abuse of that discretion.â€Â  State v. Smith, 316 S.C. 53, 55, 447 S.E.2d 175, 176 (1993).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when a trial courtâ€™s decision is unsupported by the evidence or controlled by an error of law.â€Â  State v. Walker, 366 S.C. 643, 656, 623 S.E.2d 122, 129 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  
The State argues there was no evidence in the record to support a finding that Doeâ€™s testimony was influenced by Cynthiaâ€™s coaching. Â We disagree.Â  All parties acknowledge that Cynthia acted inappropriately making mouthing words to Doe and shaking her head during his testimony. Â The trial judge was in a better position than we are to determine whether Doe may have been influenced by the coaching.Â  He was present in the courtroom to view the visual relationship between the relevant participants during the testimony and was able to observe Doeâ€™s demeanor and hear his responses.Â  See State v. Squires, 248 S.C. 239, 246, 149 S.E.2d 601, 604 (1966) (deferring to â€œ[t]he trial judge, who was in position to know and observe all of the circumstancesâ€ and conclude an argument was not prejudicial); Collins v. Collins, 283 S.C. 526, 529, 324 S.E.2d 82, 84 (Ct. App. 1984) (â€œ[T]he trial judge, who observes the witnesses and is in a better position to judge their demeanor and veracity, is given broad discretion.â€).Â  The trial judge also observed Cynthia and heard the testimony of the witnesses who saw her inappropriate gestures during Doeâ€™s testimony.Â  
  There was evidence in the record to support the judgeâ€™s decision, so that the granting of a new trial was not an abuse of discretion. 
Additionally, we are not persuaded by the Stateâ€™s argument that Smith waived his right to request a mistrial when he failed to contemporaneously object to the coaching.Â  First, it is not clear from the record that the coaching was apparent to Smithâ€™s counsel during Doeâ€™s cross-examination.Â  The trial judge acknowledges in the record that he himself did not see the coaching when it first occurred.Â  It appears that Smith brought the misconduct to the courtâ€™s attention as soon as the extent of the coaching was revealed.Â  The trial judge did initially determine that Smith waived any objection.Â  However, the judge only had a portion of the relevant information before him and did not have the luxury of time, as do appellate courts, to weigh and ponder the question. Â As trial judges are often required to do, he had to make a ruling on the spot.Â  When that initial decision was made, he did not have the benefit of the testimony at the hearing from witnesses who were in a better position to see what had transpired between Doe and Cynthia.Â  Once privy to this additional information, the judge became convinced that the chance of prejudice to Smith was much greater than he initially thought.Â  Surely, under such circumstances, a judge has the latitude to change his mind about a prior ruling.Â  Just as a judge retains the power to change a ruling on a motion in limine based on developments at trial, a judge has the prerogative to change his mind with respect to a ruling when reflection and information convince him that his prior ruling was incorrect.Â  See State v. Floyd, 295 S.C. 518, 520, 369 S.E.2d 842, 842 (1988) (stating a ruling on a motion in limine is subject to change based on events at trial).Â  In the instant case, the judge heard additional evidence, considered the matter, and concluded that his prior ruling regarding waiver was not proper under these circumstances. Â 
It is notable that the trial judge did not direct a verdict in Smithâ€™s favor or exonerate him in any way.Â  This decision means that Smith will be tried again, and Doeâ€™s testimony in that case will be â€œuncoachedâ€ and free of any impermissible influence. 
For all the foregoing reasons the decision of the trial court is Â 
AFFIRMED.
SHORT, J., concurs.
GOOLSBY, J., dissents in a separate opinion.
GOOLSBY, J. (dissenting):Â  I would reverse the order granting Smith a new trial and for that reason I respectfully dissent.
John Doe, Smithâ€™s son, testified that Smith abused him when Doe was six or seven years old during visits to Smithâ€™s home.Â  During Doeâ€™s testimony, several people in the courtroom observed Doeâ€™s aunt, Cynthia, mouthing words and shaking her head up and down and side to side, seemingly in response to the questions Doe was asked.
After Doe finished testifying, Smith made a motion for the trial court to remove Cynthia from the courtroom before Richard Roe, Doeâ€™s brother, testified.Â  Smith alleged, based on information from other individuals in the courtroom,  inappropriate â€œmotions and mouth movement and things going back and forthâ€ between Cynthia and Doe occurred during Doeâ€™s testimony.
Cynthia left the courtroom voluntarily.Â  Smith did not use this opportunity to advance any further arguments on the coaching issue or move for a mistrial.Â  Smith received the relief he sought in the motion; the removal of Cynthia from the courtroom.[4]Â  As a result, Smithâ€™s motion to remove Cynthia from the courtroom did not preserve the coaching issue for further review.
Roe, who was fifteen at the time of trial, testified in an in camera Lyle[5] hearing that he suffered similar abuse from Smith.Â  Following Roeâ€™s testimony, Smith moved for a mistrial on the ground that Cynthia coached Doe during Doeâ€™s testimony.[6]Â  One of Smithâ€™s attorneys explained to the trial court:

I believe I saw [Doe] looking in the direction of his aunt to seek an answer.Â  It was not until I finished with his questioning that I sat down that I was informed by co[-]counsel and other members of the court, all in the courtroom, that that, in fact, was the magnitude of what was taking place.Â  

Smith waited until after Roe finished testifying before requesting a mistrial.
The trial court ruled that Smith waived the issue because his attorneys knew of Cynthiaâ€™s conduct during Doeâ€™s testimony but did not request a mistrial or immediately raise the issue and allow the court the chance to take appropriate action.[7]Â  Smith renewed his motion for a mistrial at the conclusion of the Stateâ€™s case and again at the close of evidence.Â  The trial court denied the motions.
After his conviction and sentencing, Smith moved for a new trial.Â  Smith presented testimony from court officials who witnessed Cynthiaâ€™s alleged coaching of Doe.Â  One of the witnesses, Stephanie Smart, testified that she observed Cynthia attempting to coach Doe during his testimony and brought it to the attention of one of Smithâ€™s attorneys during Doeâ€™s testimony.Â  As pointed out earlier, Smith did not request a mistrial until after Roeâ€™s testimony, even despite being informed of Cynthiaâ€™s misconduct during Doeâ€™s testimony.
The trial court granted Smithâ€™s motion for a new trial.Â  In doing so, the trial court made the following findings of fact: 1) Cynthia used body language and other non-verbal signals in an attempt to communicate with Doe; 2) this communication may have overridden Doeâ€™s free will; and 3) this behavior and the potential for corruption of Doeâ€™s testimony denied Smith his right to a fair trial.
Having ruled that Smith waived the coaching issue during trial and absent a contemporaneous objection by Smithâ€™s counsel, I believe the trial court erred by granting Smithâ€™s motion for a new trial on the same issue.[8]Â  I would reverse the order granting Smith a new trial and reinstate his sentence.

[1]  We refer to the victim as John Doe and his older brother as Richard Roe to protect the identities of the minors involved.Â  
[2]  State v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 406, 118 S.E. 803 (1923).
[3]  Doe was not examined during the post-trial hearing as by then he and Roe had returned to their home out of state.
[4]Â  See Bowman v. Bowman, 357 S.C. 146, 160, 591 S.E.2d 654, 661 (Ct. App. 2004) (citations omitted) (â€œ[A] party cannot complain when it receives the relief for which it has asked.â€).
[5] Â State v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 406, 118 S.E. 803 (1923).
[6]Â  See State v. Lynn, 277 S.C. 222, 226, 284 S.E.2d 786, 789 (1981) (â€œFailure to contemporaneously object to the question now advanced as prejudicial cannot be later bootstrapped by a motion for a mistrial.â€).
[7] Â See State v. Sullivan, 310 S.C. 311, 314, 426 S.E.2d 766, 768 (1993) (noting that an appellant must object at his first opportunity to preserve an issue for appellate review).
[8]Â  See State v. Groome, 274 S.C. 189, 192, 262 S.E.2d 31, 32 (1980) (â€œFailure to contemporaneously object to the questions now advanced as prejudicial cannot be later bootstrapped by a motion for a mistrial.â€); McElveen v. Ferre, 299 S.C. 377, 381, 385 S.E.2d 39, 41 (Ct. App. 1989) (upholding the trial courtâ€™s denial of a motion for a new trial where the error was not preserved); see also Idaho v. Higgins, 836 P.2d 536, 550 (Idaho 1992) (holding the trial court had no basis to grant a new trial where the issue was not properly preserved during the trial); Louisiana v. Marcotte, 817 So. 2d 1245, 1250 (La. Ct. App. 2002) (â€œIn our opinion, a motion for new trial does not preserve or revive an issue not properly and timely raised by objection.Â  This is true because, by the time
a new-trial motion is made, the trial court has lost its best opportunity to correct the error at issue.â€); Schacher v. Dunne, 820 P.2d 865, 867 (Or. Ct. App. 1991) (â€œAn error that is not preserved cannot properly form the basis for a motion for a new trial.â€); Carlson Mining Co. v. Titan Coal Co., 494 A.2d 1127 (Pa. Super. Ct. 1985) (noting a trial court may only award a new trial on questions that are preserved); 66 C.J.S. New Trial Â§ 17 (1998) (â€œAlthough there is some authority to the contrary, generally matters not properly pleaded, or put in issue, or preserved, may not be raised on a motion for a new trial.â€).

title: State v. Kelly
description: The Court of Appeals affirmed the circuit court's instructions following a jury polling where one juror was not comfortable with the guilty verdict.  The circuit court did not err in sending the jury back for more deliberations or in declining to give an Allen v. United States charge.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Carl Vernon Kelly, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Paul M. Burch, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4203
Submitted January 1, 2007 â€“ Filed February 5, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, Office of the Attorney General, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Shawn L. Reeves, all of Columbia;Â  and Solicitor Ralph E. Hoisington, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.: Carl Kelly appeals the circuit courtâ€™s decision not to grant a mistrial and not to issue an Allen[1] charge after a juror retracted her guilty verdicts during jury polling.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Carl Kelly stood trial before a jury on charges of assault and battery with intent to kill, armed robbery, first-degree burglary, and kidnapping.Â  At the close of trial, the jury informed the judge they had reached a unanimous verdict of guilty on each charge. Â After the jury read the verdict, the defense requested the jury be polled. 
Upon polling, eleven of the jurors reported that their verdicts were guilty.Â  One juror, however, reported that she was â€œnot comfortableâ€ with the verdict. Â The trial judge then said:

The [c]ourt fully understands that a juror certainly has been put in a position where youâ€™re not comfortable with what you do.Â  Iâ€™m not comfortable many times in my job up here.Â  I understand that.Â  But I needâ€”if you donâ€™t mind, if you would, I need you to respond to the question: Is this still your verdict? 

The juror then responded â€œI really donâ€™t know.Â  I canâ€™t . . . (shaking her head side to side) no.â€ 
The trial judge then sent the jury back to the jury room to continue deliberations â€œto see if [they could not] reach a verdict.â€ Â Kellyâ€™s defense attorneys then made an objection to the courtâ€™s statement, which they called a de facto Allen charge. Â They also made a motion for a mistrial and requested a full Allen charge.Â  Nearly two hours later, the jury returned with a guilty verdict on each charge. Â This verdict survived a jury polling. 
LAW AND ANALYSIS
Kelly argues the court erred by failing to declare a mistrial or alternatively by failing to issue a full Allen charge after the juror retracted her guilty verdicts during jury polling.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe granting or refusing of a motion for a mistrial lies within the sound discretion of the trial court and its ruling will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  State v. Harris, 340 S.C. 59, 63, 530 S.E.2d 626, 627-28 (2000).Â  A mistrial should be declared only when absolutely necessary.Â  Id. at 63, 530 S.E.2d at 628.Â  In order to receive a mistrial, the defendant must show error and resulting prejudice.Â  Id.Â  
The trial judge must be satisfied that the verdict is unanimous and must conduct a jury poll at the request of either party.Â  State v. Linder, 276 S.C. 304, 309, 278 S.E.2d 335, 338 (1981).Â  â€œPolling is a practice whereby the court determines from the jurors individually whether they assented [to] and still assent to the verdict.â€Â  Id. at 308, 278 S.E.2d at 338. Â â€œIf it is made known to the court when it is time to render the verdict that any juror does not assent to it, the verdict cannot be received and the jury should retire to their room until they have agreed.â€Â  State v. Singleton, 319 S.C. 312, 316, 460 S.E.2d 573, 576 (1995).Â  A judge has a duty to urge the jury to reach a verdict, but he may not coerce them.Â  Id. at 316, 460 S.E2d at 575.Â  
In criminal cases, this Court sits to review errors of law only.Â  State v. Staten, 364 S.C. 7, 15, 610 S.E.2d 823, 827 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  â€œAn appellate court will not reverse the trial courtâ€™s decision regarding jury instructions unless the trial court abused its discretion.â€Â  State v. Williams, 367 S.C. 192, 195, 624 S.E.2d 443, 445 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  â€œThe requesting party must have been prejudiced by the trial courtâ€™s failure to give the instruction in order to warrant reversal on appeal.â€Â  Id. at 195-96, 624 S.E.2d at 445.Â Â  
In this case, when the juror stated she was not comfortable and ultimately not in agreement with the verdicts, the trial judge sent the jury back into the deliberation room to see if they could arrive at a unanimous verdict.Â  It was within the trial judgeâ€™s discretion to either grant a mistrial or send the jury back for deliberations.Â  The juror did not indicate that she was coerced into voting for a guilty verdict, nor did she indicate that the jury was hopelessly deadlocked.Â  Therefore, declaring a mistrial was not an absolute necessity, and no prejudice resulted from sending the jury back for more deliberations.Â  
Here, the judge followed the same procedure affirmed by the Supreme Court in State v. Roper, 274 S.C. 14, 260 S.E.2d 705 (1979).Â  In Roper, one juror indicated she had her doubts about the verdict.Â  After questioning that juror, the trial judge sent the jury back in for more deliberations with the instruction that any verdict must be unanimous.Â  The Supreme Court ruled that the judgeâ€™s instructions were courteous and expeditious and were not coercive.Â  
Likewise, the questions asked in State v. Singleton, 319 S.C. 312, 315-16, 460 S.E.2d 573, 575-76 (1995) were found to be appropriate â€œto ensure that the juror did not misunderstand the verdict and to confirm that the verdict was unanimous.â€Â  In Singleton, when asked if the guilty verdict was still his verdict, the juror answered â€œno.â€Â  The judge then said: â€œGo back in your jury room to continue your deliberations.Â  Iâ€™m told this was a unanimous verdict. Is this your verdict?â€Â  The juror then answered: â€œIt is now.â€Â  Singleton, at 315, 460 S.E.2d at 575.Â  
A comparison of the instructions in the case at bar to the proper instructions in Roper and Singleton shows that the instructions given in this case were noncoercive and did not prejudice Kellyâ€™s case.Â  
Kelly also argues the trial court erred in failing to issue a full Allen charge after the juror retracted her guilty verdict.Â  An Allen charge, also known as a â€œDynamiteâ€ or â€œHammerâ€ charge, is to be used when the jury has expressed a deadlock and cannot come to a unanimous conclusion.Â  See Allen v. United States, 164 U.S. 492 (1896).Â  There is no case law requiring or suggesting that an Allen charge be given when a juror retracts her verdict during polling and this Court will not impose such a requirement.
Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.[2]Â 
HEARN C.J., and KITTREDGE, J., concur.

[1] Allen v. United States, 164 U.S. 492 (1896).
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Roland v. Heritage Litchfield, Inc.
description: Respondents, the owners of eleven condominium units in the Avian Forest development, sued Appellants for numerous causes of action after discovering mold in the firewall area of the condominiums.  The trial court granted Respondents' motion for partial summary judgment as to liability.  Appellants appeal, arguing (1) issues of material fact exist with regard to both the extent of the mold problem and its causation, and (2) Respondents do not own the common areas where the mold was found.  We affirm.
text:
Roland v. Heritage Litchfield


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Stella Sue Roland, Steven Roland, Charles Wright, Patricia Wright, Sea Turtles, LLC, Woods Brown, Jeanne Brown, Lois
Glander, Jean King, Michael King, Joseph Lucas, Diane Lucas, Robert Boineau and Avian Golf Investments, LLC, and Lawrence Ridgeway,
Respondents,
v.
Heritage Litchfield, Inc., Heritage Communities, Inc., and Build Star Corporation,
Appellants,
andÂ  Build Star Corporation,Third Party Plaintiff,
v.
Right Way Construction, Inc., Donovan Brothers Roofing and Restoration, Inc., and Sam's Drywall, Third Party Defendants.
      
    
  


Appeal from Georgetown County
Â Benjamin H. Culbertson, Special Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â Â  4204
Heard December 7, 2006 â€“ Filed February 5, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Eric G. Fosmire and Andrew N. Cole, both of Columbia, for Appellants.
John W. Davidson and William D. Britt, both of Columbia and Saul Gliserman, of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.: Respondents, the owners of eleven condominiums in the Avian Forest development, sued Heritage Litchfield, Inc., Heritage Communities, Inc., and Build Star Corporation (collectively Appellants)[1] for numerous causes of action after discovering mold in the firewall area of the condominiums.Â  The trial court granted Respondentsâ€™ motion for partial summary judgment as to liability.Â  Appellants appeal, arguing (1) issues of material fact exist with regard to both the extent of the mold problem and its causation, and (2) Respondents do not own the common areas where the mold was found.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Avian Forest is a condominium development in the Litchfield Beach area.Â  The development has numerous buildings, each of which are two stories tall and contain four condominiums.Â  The buildings are divided such that two condominiums are on the ground floor, and two are on the second floor. Â A firewall separates each individual condominium.
The first buildings erected in the development were buildings 19, 20, and 21, all of which were built during roughly the same time period, beginning in the Spring of 1999.Â  Eleven of the twelve units in these buildings were sold to the Respondents in late 1999. The twelfth unit never sold.
During the construction of these first three buildings, it is undisputed that the firewalls were erected prior to the roofs.Â  Gwyn Hardister, the president of Heritage Litchfield, testified the firewalls were rained on while they were unprotected by a roof.Â  Tommy Hooks, the assistant project manager, also testified that before the roof was built, â€œmoisture had accumulated in those walls and sometime thereafter we saw the signs of mold . . . .Â  Mold was evident in those firewalls.â€Â  
In March of 2000, a plumbing leak in building 19 led to the discovery of mold on the common firewall between the units. Appellants hired a mold remediation and investigation company, whose investigator determined that the mold had toxic characteristics and was present in the firewalls of all three buildings.Â  The investigator informed Hardister about the mold problem, who in turn advised Respondents not to live in their condominiums.Â  
Respondents filed causes of action against Appellants, alleging breach of the implied warranty of habitability, breach of the implied warranty of workmanlike service, breach of express warranty, and negligence.Â  Appellants answered, and both sides filed motions for partial summary judgment. Respondents sought summary judgment as to liability, and Appellants sought summary judgment as to Respondentsâ€™ standing to allege any injury to the common elements of the buildings.Â  The trial court granted Respondentsâ€™ motion and denied Appellantsâ€™ motion. This appeal followed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn reviewing the grant of summary judgment, [the appellate court] applies the same standard that governs the trial court under Rule 56, SCRCP: summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Pittman v. Grand Strand Entmâ€™t, Inc., 363 S.C. 531, 536, 611 S.E.2d 922, 925 (2005).Â  The appellate court therefore reviews all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Id.Â  Once the moving party meets the initial burden of showing an absence of evidentiary support for the opponentâ€™s case, the nonmoving party must come forward with specific facts showing there is a genuine issue for trial and cannot simply rest on mere allegations or denials contained in the pleadings.Â  Miller v. Blumenthal Mills, Inc., 365 S.C. 204, 220, 616 S.E.2d 722, 730 (Ct. App. 2005). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellants argue summary judgment should have been denied because there are material facts in dispute with regard to causation and the nature and extent of the mold problem.Â  We disagree.
During the summary judgment hearing, Respondents presented numerous depositions wherein agents of the Appellants admitted the mold was caused by the firewallsâ€™ exposure during rainy weather.Â  Appellants argue there is a question of fact regarding how much mold was caused by the firewalls exposure during construction and how much mold was caused by other factors, such as the Respondentsâ€™ failure to properly maintain their air conditioning systems.Â  However, no evidence was presented to the trial court suggesting Respondents contributed to their mold problem, nor was there any evidence suggesting that anything other than the saturation of the firewalls during construction caused the mold in all three buildings.Â  Because mere allegations of comparative negligence are not sufficient to raise an issue of material fact, we find summary judgment was proper with regard to causation.Â  See Miller, 365 S.C. at 220, 616 S.E.2d at 730 (explaining that once the moving party meets its initial burden, the nonmoving party must come forward with specific facts showing there is a genuine issue for trial and cannot simply rest on mere allegations or denials contained in the pleadings).
In addition to their argument regarding causation, Appellants also contend the extent of the mold problem is in dispute.Â  Specifically, they argue there is a question of fact regarding the habitability of the condominiums because two of the unit owners rented their units and there was no evidence in the record that the renters complained of the unitsâ€™ conditions.Â  Additionally, Appellants point out there was testimony that the mold was not dangerous â€œas long as you donâ€™t disturb it, meaning open walls so that the mold is airborne.â€Â  After a careful review of the record, we find no issue of material fact with regard to the habitability of the units.
While two of the Respondents did indeed rent their units, they ceased renting them once they learned of the mold problem.Â  Furthermore, the â€œhabitabilityâ€ of a dwelling does not turn on whether a person actually lives there; rather habitability is defined as the â€œ[t]he condition of a building in which inhabitants can live free of serious defects that might harm health and safety . . . .â€Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary (8th ed. 2004).Â  Here, the only evidence in the record showed Respondentsâ€™ units were unsafe due to the toxic mold found between the walls.Â  Gwyn Hardister, the president of Heritage Communities, testified that he contacted Phoenix EnviroCorp to identify whether a mold problem existed in the units.Â  From that investigation, Hardister learned there were high levels of toxic mold in the air samples tested.Â  Hardister told the owners about the mold and advised them not to live in their units. Â Although Appellants attempt to isolate one line of Hardisterâ€™s testimony in which he said â€œas long as you donâ€™t disturb [the mold], meaning open walls so that the mold is airborne, itâ€™s not dangerousâ€ to support their contention there is an issue of material fact, we find this statement, when read in context, does not preclude summary judgment.Â  Later in Hardisterâ€™s testimony, he explained the mold could be â€œdisturbedâ€ simply by occupying the units because fluctuations in the humidity, temperature, and air pressure of the units could produce higher levels of the mold.Â  Because neither Hardisterâ€™s testimony nor the rental of the units raise an issue of material fact regarding the unitsâ€™ habitability, summary judgment was appropriate.
Next, Appellants argue the trial court erred in granting summary judgment as to liability because the area impacted by mold is a common area belonging to the homeownersâ€™ association, not Respondents.Â  We disagree.
The Master Deed of the Avian Forest Development specifically states:

[E]ach UNIT shall be conveyed and treated as an individual property capable of independent use and fee simple ownership, and the Owner or Owners of each UNIT shall own, as an appurtenance to the ownership of each said UNIT, an undivided interest in the COMMON ELEMENTS . . . .

(emphasis added). Furthermore, neither the Master Deed nor the By-Laws of the Avian Forest Homeownersâ€™ Association grants the homeownersâ€™ association an ownership interest in the common elements.Â  We therefore find no question of material fact exists regarding ownership of the common elements which would preclude summary judgment as to liability.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the order of the trial court granting partial summary judgment with regard to liability is
AFFIRMED.
BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] Heritage Litchfield, Inc. was the main developer of Avian Forest, and Build Star Corporation was the general contractor for the buildings.Â  Both Heritage Litchfield and Build Star are wholly owned by Heritage Communities, Inc.Â

title: Altman v. Griffith
description: This is an appeal from a family court order awarding custody of the parties' minor child to Ernest Bartlett Altman.  Vicky Griffith appeals.  We affirm.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Ernest Bartlett Altman, Respondent,
v.
Vicky Griffith, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Marion D. Myers, Family Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  4205
Heard December 5, 2006 â€“ Filed February 5, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Donald Bruce Clark, Robert Rosen, both of Charleston and J. Mark Taylor, of West Columbia, for Appellant.
D. Mark Stokes, of North Charleston and John Graham Altman, III, of Hanahan, for Respondent.
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.:Â  This is an appeal from a family court order awarding custody of the partiesâ€™ minor child to Ernest Bartlett Altman (Father).Â  Vicky Griffith (Mother) appeals.[1]Â  We affirm.Â  
I.
We are aware of our right to conduct a de novo review in an appeal from the family court and find facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Nasser-Moghaddassi v. Moghaddassi, 364 S.C. 182, 189, 612 S.E.2d 707, 711 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing Emery v. Smith, 361 S.C. 207, 213, 603 S.E.2d 598, 601 (Ct. App. 2004)).Â  With respect to custody determinations, however, this court and our supreme court have consistently shown deference to family court judges in electing between fit parents.Â  In the case before us, although both parents were burdened with â€œshortcomings,â€ there is no challenge to the finding of fitness.Â  For obvious and compelling reasons, as an appellate court, we are reticent to substitute our judgment on the custody determination between fit parents for that of the family court judge.
Our deference to the family courtâ€™s findings is especially warranted here, for the ultimate determination rests primarily on the trial judgeâ€™s assessment of witness demeanor and credibility.Â  In gauging between fit parents as to who would better serve the best interests and welfare of the child in a custodial setting, the family court judge is in a superior position to appellate judges who are left only to review the cold record.Â  For this reason, custody determinations largely rest in the sound discretion of the family court judge.Â  Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996) (â€œ[T]he appellate court should be reluctant to substitute its own evaluation of the evidence on child custody for that of the [family] court.â€); Brown v. Brown, 362 S.C. 85, 89, 606 S.E.2d 785, 787 (Ct. App. 2004) (same); Shirley v. Shirley, 342 S.C. 324, 330-31, 536 S.E.2d 427, 230 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œCustody decisions are matters left largely to the discretion of the [family] court.â€); Paparella v. Paparella, 340 S.C. 186, 189, 531 S.E.2d 297, 299 (Ct. App. 2000) (noting appellate courts should
be reluctant to supplant the trial courtâ€™s evaluation of witness credibility regarding child custody).Â  Indeed, our supreme court has held â€œ[w]hen both parties are fit and proper to have child custody, the trial judge must make the election.â€Â  Jones v. Ard, 265 S.C. 423, 426, 219 S.E.2d 358, 359-60 (1975).
This deferential scope of review is consistent with the general approach to accord respect to a family court judgeâ€™s factual findings, as reflected in the following often cited principle: â€œNor must we ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.â€Â  Lanier v. Lanier, 364 S.C. 211, 215, 612 S.E.2d 456, 458 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing Cherry v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d 541, 541 (1981)).Â  â€œ[W]here there is disputed evidence, the appellate court may adhere to the findings of the family court.â€Â  Scott v. Scott, 354 S.C. 118, 124, 579 S.E.2d 620, 623 (2003).
 II.Â Â Â 
Mother and Father met in the spring of 1998 and began living together soon thereafter.Â  The couple never married.Â  Mother and Father had a rocky relationship almost from the beginning.Â  Mother gave birth to the partiesâ€™ son on May 27, 1999.Â  The birth of their child did little to solidify the tumultuous relationship between the couple.Â  Regrettably, in the partiesâ€™ acrimonious relationship, each parent used the child as leverage against the other.Â  The couple experienced many separations and attempts at reconciliation.Â  
Father regularly used marijuana.Â  He even publicly advocated marijuana use, and he ran a business that catered to the marijuana-smoking crowd under the guise of a â€œmusic store.â€Â  The business distributed drug related paraphernalia, such as pipes commonly used to smoke marijuana.Â  Mother regularly used marijuana and alcohol, even when pregnant with the partiesâ€™ child.Â  Mother also took prescribed antidepressants and tranquilizers, including Paxil, Zoloft, Tranxene, and Valium. 
In October 2002, Mother and Father permanently separated.Â  At that time Mother took the child and moved in with her parents.Â  In an effort to see the child, Father called and wrote Mother â€œon a regular basis,â€ but Mother avoided him.Â  Rather than permit Father to see his son, Mother â€œdirected [Father] to speak to my attorney.â€Â  Father was denied any contact with his son until he filed this action in January 2003.
In February 2003, the family court issued a temporary order granting temporary custody of the child to the maternal and paternal grandparents â€œwith visitation extended to the mother and father at times agreeable to the respective grandparents.â€Â  The temporary order further noted â€œgreat concernsâ€ with both parents.
III.
Judge Marion D. Myers presided over the final hearing.Â  Following a lengthy trial (August 30, 2004 through September 8, 2004), the learned and experienced family court judge found both parents fit and awarded custody to Father.Â  There is no challenge to the finding of fitness.Â  
Contested custody cases often bring out the worst in parents.Â  This case was no exception, as each parent relished the opportunity to disparage the other.Â  Each parent gave the other plenty of ammunition, which Judge Myers charitably described as their â€œshortcomings.â€Â  As noted, the parents used the child as a pawn in their conflicts.Â  They also used illegal drugs.Â  The evidence additionally revealed Motherâ€™s unmistakable tendency to be self-absorbed and self-pitying.Â  The picture of both parties improved during the pendency of the litigation.Â  Judge Myersâ€™ finding of fitness reflects his view that the improvement is genuine, as opposed to judicially motivated posturing.
After carefully weighing the evidence, Judge Myers found that despite the parentsâ€™ â€œshortcomings,â€ neither parent â€œcan now be deemed to be an unfit parent and neither partyâ€™s love for this child is in doubt.â€Â  (emphasis in original).Â  Judge Myers considered the â€œtotality of the circumstancesâ€ and concluded: (1) â€œthe child in the long run would benefit more from being in fatherâ€™s custody than motherâ€™sâ€; (2) â€œthe father would provide the child with the best and probably the only opportunity to have a good relationship with both of the childâ€™s parents and their familiesâ€; and (3) â€œfrom my own observation of the demeanor and attitude of the parents that the father appears to have a stronger focus on the daily welfare and care of the child than does the mother.â€Â  We find ample support in the record for these findings.
IV.
Mother contends the family court erred in failing to impose on Father the burden of demonstrating a â€œchange of circumstancesâ€ and in admitting Dr. Elizabeth Baker Gibbsâ€™ opinion testimony.Â  Mother additionally challenges the findings favoring the custody award to Father, essentially complaining about the family courtâ€™s failure to give weight to Motherâ€™s take on the evidence.
A.
Mother contends this is a â€œchange of circumstancesâ€ case in light of section 20-7-953(B) of the South Carolina Code (1985).Â  Consequently, Mother claims the family court erred by evaluating the evidence based on the â€œtotality of the circumstances.â€Â  We disagree.
We first note that this issue is not preserved.Â  Even assuming Mother asserted this argument to the family court, Judge Myers did not address the issue in the final order, and no motion for reconsideration was filed.[2]Â  â€œWhere a party raises an issue, but the issue is never ruled on by the trial court, and the party fails to file a motion to alter or amend, the issue is not preserved.â€Â  Jean Hoefer Toal, Shahin Vafai & Robert A. Muckenfuss, Appellate Practice in South Carolina 58 (2d ed. 2002) (citing S.C. Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co. v. S.E.C.U.R.E. Underwriters Risk Retention Group, 347 S.C. 333, 554 S.E.2d 870 (Ct. App. 2001)).Â  We address the issue, however, because â€œprocedural rules are subservient to the courtâ€™s duty to zealously guard the rights of minors.â€Â  Joiner ex rel. Rivas v. Rivas, 342 S.C. 102, 107, 536 S.E.2d 372, 374 (2000).Â  
Motherâ€™s specific contention is that a statute concerning paternity, section 20-7-953(B), imposes on Father the burden of showing a substantial change of circumstances to gain custody.Â  Section 20-7-953(B) provides: 

Unless the court orders otherwise, the custody of an illegitimate child is solely in the natural mother unless the mother has relinquished her rights to the child. If paternity has been acknowledged or adjudicated, the father may petition the court for rights of visitation or custody in a proceeding before the court apart from an action to establish paternity.

The issue as framed by Mother presents the following question: when parents are not married, does the law mandate a change of circumstances burden on every father who seeks custody?Â  The answer is â€œno.â€Â  We find nothing in the language of the statute (which is found in the subarticle titled â€œDetermination of Paternityâ€) suggesting the result advocated by Mother.Â  See Floyd v. Nationwide Mut. Ins. Co., 367 S.C. 253, 260, 626 S.E.2d 6, 10 (2005) (â€œThe cardinal rule of statutory construction is to ascertain and effectuate the intent of the legislature.â€).Â Â  In giving a father the right to petition the family court for custody, the statute makes no mention of a change of circumstances burden.Â  This plain reading of the statute is in accord with the general legal principle that the imposition of a change of circumstances burden applies when a parent seeks to alter a prior custody order.Â  See Latimer v. Farmer, 360 S.C. 375, 381, 602 S.E.2d 32, 35 (2004) (holding that when a previous order addressing the issue of custody exists, a showing of changed circumstances is required for a court to grant a change in custody). Â Â Â 
Another legal principle in line with our holding today is the established rule in South Carolina that â€œin custody matters, the father and mother are in parity as to entitlement to the custody of a child.â€Â  Brown v. Brown, 362 S.C. 85, 91, 606 S.E.2d 785, 788 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œ[T]here is no preference given to the father or mother in regard to the custody of the child[;] [t]he parents stand in perfect equipoise as the custody analysis begins.â€Â  Id.Â  We additionally note that Mother and Father were living together when their child was born, and there was never any question as to paternity.Â  The family court in this case was presented with an initial custody determination.Â  In an initial custody determination, the parents are on equal footing.
We hold the family court properly determined custody based on the â€œtotality of the circumstances.â€Â  â€œThe paramount and controlling factor in every custody dispute is the best interests of the children.â€Â  Nasser-Moghaddassi v. Moghaddassi, 364 S.C. 182, 191, 612 S.E.2d 707, 711 (Ct. App. 2005); see also Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 11, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996) (â€œThe welfare and best interests of the child are paramount in custody disputes.â€).Â  In making initial custody decisions â€œthe totality of the circumstances peculiar to each case constitutes the only scale upon which the ultimate decision can be weighed.â€Â  Wheeler v. Gill, 307 S.C. 94, 99, 413 S.E.2d 860, 865 (Ct. App. 1992) (quoting
Davenport v. Davenport, 265 S.C. 524, 527, 220 S.E.2d 228, 230 (1975)). 
B.
Mother next asserts the family court erred in admitting much of Dr. Elizabeth Baker Gibbsâ€™ opinion testimony.Â  We disagree.Â  
At trial, evidence was presented about an investigation by the South Carolina Department of Social Services (DSS) concerning alleged abuse of the child.Â  On May 3, 2004, after the child spent a weekend with Father, the maternal grandmother, Johanna Garner, noticed bruising on the child and took him to the doctor.Â  Dr. Meghan Geils examined the child and filed a report with DSS, although she acknowledged she lacked extensive training in child abuse matters and also candidly admitted she was not â€œable to determine the cause of the bruises.â€Â  Garner emphasized that she was â€œconcernedâ€ about the child, even though Dr. Geils reported the child â€œwasnâ€™t upsetâ€ and seemed like â€œ[j]ust a normal little boy.â€Â  
This scenario repeated itself on May 17 when Garner brought the child to Dr. Geilsâ€™ office.Â  Garner expressed the â€œsame concerns.â€Â  Dr. Geils observed a bruise but further noted the child was â€œhappyâ€ and â€œfine.â€Â  When asked what she did â€œas a result of that visit,â€ Dr. Geils responded, â€œI didnâ€™t do anything. The grandmother . . . had already taken pictures and had already re-notified DSS that there was another abuse.â€Â  
DSS investigated the abuse allegations against Father and determined the allegations were â€œunfounded.â€Â  
Confronted with the abuse allegations (but prior to the â€œunfoundedâ€ determination by DSS), Father took the child to the Carolina Medical Assessment Center.Â  Dr. Elizabeth Baker Gibbs is the Medical Director of the Carolina Medical Assessment Center.Â  The Center provides numerous child related services, including forensic medical services for victims of child abuse.Â  Dr. Gibbs examined the child and interviewed the parents and Garner.
Father presented Dr. Gibbs as an expert witness â€œon whether the child was a victim of abuse and neglect.â€Â  The family court, without objection, qualified Dr. Gibbs as an expert.Â  Dr. Gibbs testified the bruises and abrasions on the child were â€œnon-specific.â€Â  Dr. Gibbs specifically stated the childâ€™s â€œlesions were non-specific which would be lesions that we would commonly find on him[,] especially an active child his age.â€[3]Â  The child informed Dr. Gibbs that he had fallen off a chair at Garnerâ€™s house.Â  It was Dr. Gibbsâ€™ opinion that the child had not been abused.
As part of her evaluation, Dr. Gibbs spoke with Father, Mother, and Garner.Â  According to Dr. Gibbs:

From the first time I talked with [Father], his focus was really almost entirely based around [the child]. . . . Â When I talked to [Mother], her focus was around the effect all of this was having on her; not the effect that this was having on [the child] . . . .Â  We tried several different techniques and we were unable to get [Mother] to shift her focus to a child-focus perspective. 

Mother did not object to the foregoing testimony and, consequently, she may not now assign error to its admission and consideration by the family court.Â  Failure to object when evidence is offered constitutes a waiver of the right to object, and the issue may not then be raised for the first time on appeal.Â  Crawford v. Crawford, 321 S.C. 511, 514, 469 S.E.2d 622, 624 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  Mother only objected when Dr. Gibbs was asked how long it would take for Mother to learn to be more child-focused.Â  The family court found the testimony within Dr. Gibbsâ€™ expertise and overruled Motherâ€™s objection.Â  Thereafter, Dr. Gibbs opined:

Either way, my concern is that the conflict is going to continue which can be very damaging to children.Â  I would be concerned that if [Mother] has the primary care and control, that the conflict will continue at the current level or maybe even more so.Â  If [Father] had primary care and control, I do see him more motivated in decreasing the conflict.

We find no merit to Motherâ€™s challenge to Dr. Gibbsâ€™ testimony.Â  Rule 702, SCRE, provides: â€œIf scientific, technical, or other specialized knowledge will assist the trier of fact to understand the evidence or to determine a fact in issue, a witness qualified as an expert by knowledge, skill, experience, training, or education, may testify thereto in the form of an opinion or otherwise.â€Â  Generally, â€œ[w]hether a witness has qualified as an expert, and whether his opinion is admissible on a fact in issue, are matters resting largely in the discretion of the trial judge.â€Â  Prince v. Assâ€™n Petroleum Carriers, 262 S.C. 358, 365, 204 S.E.2d 575, 579 (1974).Â  â€œA trial courtâ€™s ruling to exclude or admit expert testimony will not be disturbed on appeal absent a clear abuse of discretion.â€Â  Mizell v. Glover, 351 S.C. 392, 406, 570 S.E.2d 176, 183 (2002).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when the ruling is based on an error of law or a factual conclusion that is without evidentiary support.â€Â  Fields v. Regâ€™l Med. Ctr. Orangeburg, 363 S.C. 19, 26, 609 S.E.2d 506, 509 (2005).Â  
The record indicates Dr. Gibbs has impressive credentials in dealing with dysfunctional families and possesses specialized knowledge in forensic medicine in evaluating allegations of child abuse.Â  Dr. Gibbsâ€™ knowledge, skill, experience, training, and education clearly satisfy the requirements of Rule 702.Â  We conclude the family court did not abuse its discretion in admitting Dr. Gibbsâ€™ so-called â€œexpandedâ€ testimony.Â  It is our judgment that Motherâ€™s tardy objection to Dr. Gibbsâ€™ testimony goes more to the weight of the evidence than its admissibility.
Furthermore, we would be hard-pressed to characterize any error in admitting Dr. Gibbsâ€™s â€œexpandedâ€ testimony as amounting to reversible error.Â  To warrant reversal based on the admission or exclusion of evidence, the complaining party must prove both error and resulting prejudice.Â  Hanahan v. Simpson, 326 S.C. 140, 156, 485 S.E.2d 903, 911 (1997).Â  As pointed out by Mother, the family court relied in part on Dr. Gibbsâ€™ testimony in awarding custody to Father.Â  Yet the record contains other evidence of Motherâ€™s focus on herself.Â  
For example, Mother kept a journal (admitted without objection) in 2002 as a result of a self-help book, Self Matters, written by Dr. Phil McGraw.Â  Examples of Motherâ€™s journal entries include: â€œI over-exaggerate things to create drama and appear to be the victim in most situationsâ€; â€œI lack basic coping skills and have used alcohol and/or drugs as a way to anesthetizeâ€; â€œI can be unpleasant and resentful when I donâ€™t get my wayâ€; and â€œIâ€™m the victim,â€ a statement Mother underlined three times.Â  Based on the journal entries, Mother admitted on cross-examination that she has â€œgeneral feelings of being taken advantage of, lied to, gossiped about, [and] used and abused.â€ 
We cite this example not to disparage Mother in any way.Â  As noted by Judge Myers, Mother has made laudable strides during the pendency of this custody suit.Â  Judge Myers found that Mother is now a fit parent.Â  We cite this evidence only to illustrate that Dr. Gibbsâ€™ testimony is certainly not the only evidence tending to establish that Mother tends to be self-absorbed and self-pitying. Â We view Dr. Gibbsâ€™ opinion about Motherâ€™s focus on self as cumulative to other evidence in the record.
 C.
We turn finally to Motherâ€™s broad challenge that the best interests of the child dictate she be awarded custody.Â  In essence, Mother assigns error to the adverse findings against her and the more positive findings in favor of Father.Â  Mother, of course, views the evidence in a different light than determined by the family court.
We categorically reject the suggestion that the record does not support the finding that Mother has difficulty putting the childâ€™s needs first.Â  When the parents separated for the last time, Mother prevented Father from visiting the child for several months.Â  There was no valid reason to prevent Father from having any contact with his son.Â  Under these circumstances, Motherâ€™s mandate that Father contact her attorney cannot reasonably be construed as a viable response to accommodate visitation.Â  Motherâ€™s journal entries and her own testimony further buttress the family courtâ€™s finding.[4]
We additionally find support in the record for the finding that the â€œmotherâ€™s and her familyâ€™s repeated unfounded accusations and unfounded charges against the father have contributed greatly to their bad relationship and inability to communicate with each other.â€Â  Their bogus allegations that Father committed child abuse is one example.Â  Another example is Motherâ€™s complaint to law enforcement, which resulted in a charge against Father for assault with intent to kill.Â  This unfounded charge arose from an incident on August 22, 2003, when Mother claimed Father tried to kill her with his car.[5]Â  The charge was dismissed at a preliminary hearing.Â  The Solicitor apparently refused to pursue a direct indictment against Father.Â  Father had the record of his arrest expunged.Â  Our review of the evidence is in line with the family courtâ€™s finding.Â  We find no abuse of discretion.
Judge Myers found Father â€œappears to have a stronger focus on the daily welfare and care of this child than does the mother.â€Â  This finding is tied to Judge Myersâ€™ additional finding that Father â€œis committed to supporting the childâ€™s relationship with his mother notwithstanding his questionable conduct and judgment at times in other areas.â€Â  Judge Myers further noted that Father has a teenage daughter with whom he has â€œa very close [and] loving relationship.â€Â  Given the posture of the case, Mother understandably seeks to cast the evidence in a much more negative light toward Father.Â  We readily acknowledge that Fatherâ€™s side of the ledger has â€œshortcomings,â€ a fact which did not escape Judge Myers.Â  We decline, however, to recast the evidence so that the scales tip in favor of Mother. 
Judge Myers was presented with a difficult decision between fit parents.Â  In our firm judgment, the record supports the view that the childâ€™s best interest is served by an award of custody to Father.Â  We certainly cannot say that the award of custody to the Father amounts to an abuse of discretion.
There is no single factor that controls in a custody dispute, for the analysis is necessarily a fact-driven inquiry covering the totality of the circumstances.Â  Woodall, 322 S.C. at 11, 471 S.E.2d at 157 (holding that â€œwhen determining to whom custody shall be awarded . . . all of the circumstances of the particular case, and all relevant factors must be taken into considerationâ€).Â  Judge Myers thoughtfully and thoroughly considered the totality of the circumstances.
 V. 
Contested custody cases present difficult decisions for family court judges.Â  In situations where there is a striking difference in the fitness of one parent over another, the issue of custody is often resolved short of litigation.Â  Litigation seems to follow those cases where an arguably close question is presented.Â  This is such a case.Â  Motherâ€™s excellent counsel have forcefully advanced the evidence in a light most favorable to her.Â  Judge Myers was keenly aware of the partiesâ€™ respective positions and â€œshortcomings,â€ and the record manifests his recognition of the importance of the decision before him.Â  While the law reflects deference to a family court judge in deciding between fit parents, we, too, have an important responsibility to ensure that a custody award does not amount to an abuse of discretion.Â  We have canvassed the record and carefully considered the arguments presented on appeal.Â  We find ample support for Judge Myersâ€™ findings and his decision to award custody to Father.
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

[1]  Appellate counsel did not represent Mother at trial.
[2]  In an apparent attempt to circumvent our issue preservation rules, Mother now argues the family court lacked subject matter jurisdiction because Father did not expressly invoke section 20-7-953(B) as the basis for his custody claim.Â  See, e.g., Town of Hilton Head Island v. Godwin, 370 S.C. 221, __, 634 S.E.2d 59, 60-61 (Ct. App. 2006) (â€œThe lack
of subject matter jurisdiction can be raised at any time, can be raised for the first time on appeal, and can be raised sua sponte by the court.â€).Â  We disagree.Â  Subject matter jurisdiction is the power of a court to hear cases in the general class to which the proceedings in question belong.Â  Dove v. Gold Kist, Inc., 314 S.C. 235, 237-38, 442 S.E.2d 598, 600 (1994).Â  The family court has jurisdiction over custody disputes.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420 (1985 & Supp. 2005).Â  Moreover, the gravamen of Motherâ€™s argument is not the jurisdiction of the family court to hear a custody case, but the failure of the family court to impose a change of circumstances burden on Father.Â  Subject matter jurisdiction and application of a burden of proof (to a claim within the courtâ€™s jurisdiction) are different concepts.Â Â Â  
[3]  Dr. Gibbs used the term â€œlesionsâ€ to describe bruises, scratches and â€œanything on the skin that is what weâ€™re looking for.â€Â  
[4]  It is fair to say, however, that Mother does not have the self-centered market cornered.Â  The childâ€™s guardian ad litem, Graham Hawkins, had substantial contact with the parents.Â Â  Mr. Hawkins observed that both parents used the child as a pawn in their feud.Â  Both parents have â€œexposedâ€ the child â€œto quite a lot of conflict betweenâ€ them.Â  
[5]  At trial, Mother merely stated that Father â€œaccelerated the car at me.â€Â  Mother in hindsight recast the incident as less serious.Â  Yet law enforcement charged Father with assault with intent to kill based on information from Mother and Garner.Â  When Father was arraigned at a bond hearing the morning after his arrest, the press and Mother appeared.Â  Mother informed the magistrate she was afraid of Father.Â  She subsequently wrote the magistrate, claiming she was â€œscared to deathâ€ of Father.Â

title: Hardee v. McDowell
description: Concludes that a contractor must collect proof of insurance from a subcontractor on each separate job to justify shifting liability to the South Carolina Uninsured Employers' Fund for an injury to the subcontractor's employee.
text:
Hardee v. McDowell


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Anthony Hardee, Employee/Claimant,
v.
W.D. McDowell, Uninsured Employer, andÂ  S.E. Smith Construction Co., Inc., Alleged Statutory Employer,
And
Companion Property & Casualty Insurance Company, Carrier/Defendant/Appellants,
With
the South Carolina Uninsured Employersâ€™ Fund, Appearing/Respondents,
of whom
W.D. McDowell is a Respondent,
S.E. Smith Construction Co., Inc., and Companion Property & Casualty Insurance Co. are
Appellants,
And
the South Carolina Uninsured Employersâ€™ Fund is a
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4206
Heard January 9, 2007 â€“ Filed February 12, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Weston Adams, III, of Columbia and Brian Oâ€™Keefe, of Charleston, for Appellants.
Terri M. Lynch, of Mt. Pleasant and W.D. McDowell, of Loris, for Respondents.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  S.E. Smith Construction Co., Inc. and Companion Property & Casualty Insurance Co. (Smith Construction) appeal the order affirming the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commissionâ€™s finding that they must provide coverage for injuries sustained by an employee of Smith Constructionâ€™s subcontractor.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Smith Construction, a general contractor, routinely subcontracted with W.D. McDowell (McDowell) for framing work.Â  Because McDowell could not afford the lump sum payment to provide workersâ€™ compensation insurance for its employees, Smith Construction offered to pay the premium up front and deduct the insurance payments weekly from McDowellâ€™s pay.Â  On March 11, 2002, McDowell presented Smith Construction with a certificate of insurance indicating coverage from January 30, 2002 to January 30, 2003. 
During the spring and summer of 2002, McDowell worked on various jobs for Smith Construction.Â  Smith Construction, relying on the certificate of insurance on file as of March 11, did not ask McDowell for proof of insurance on these jobs.Â  In the summer of 2002, McDowell started construction of the Socastee library for Smith Construction. Â 
On September 6, 2002, Anthony Hardee, an employee of McDowell, sustained an injury at the Socastee site.Â  Several weeks later, McDowell discovered the insurer had canceled coverage on September 5, the day before Hardeeâ€™s accident.Â  
On January 16, 2003, Hardee filed a workersâ€™ compensation claim against Smith Construction and McDowell.Â  Smith Construction admitted the injury but sought indemnification from the South Carolina Uninsured Employersâ€™ Fund (the Fund) pursuant to section 42-1-415(B) of the South Carolina Code. Â 
After a hearing on Hardeeâ€™s compensation claim, the single commissioner found, inter alia, neither McDowell nor Smith Construction was aware the policy had been canceled.Â  Further, the single commissioner found although McDowell provided Smith Construction with proof of workersâ€™ compensation insurance for 2002, it did not request a certificate of insurance for the particular job in question.Â  The single commissioner therefore concluded Smith Construction failed to comply with section 42-1-415 and, accordingly, found Smith Construction liable for Hardeeâ€™s claim.Â  On appeal to the commission, Smith Construction maintained because it had collected proof of insurance prior to McDowell being â€œengaged to perform work,â€ per section 42-1-415(B), it was not liable for Hardeeâ€™s injury.Â  The commission and circuit court affirmed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The question of whether Smith Construction met the requirements of section 42-1-415 is a mixed question of law and fact.Â  There is a question of law in determining the meaning of the statuteâ€™s phrase:Â  â€œat the time the [subcontractor] was engaged to perform work.â€Â  See Charleston County Parks & Recreation Commâ€™n v. Somers, 319 S.C. 65, 67, 459 S.E.2d 841, 843 (1995) (determining legislative intent is a matter of law); Thompson v. Ford Motor Co., 200 S.C. 393, 431-32, 21 S.E.2d 34, 50 (1942) (interpretation of a statutory term is not a finding of fact).Â  There is a question of fact regarding whether the work under construction at the time of the employeeâ€™s injury was the continuation of previous work or a new job.
â€œIn a case raising a novel question of law regarding the interpretation of a statute, the appellate court is free to decide the question with no particular deference to the lower court.â€Â  Sloan v. South Carolina Bd. of Physical Therapy Examâ€™rs, 370 S.C. 452, 466-67, 636 S.E.2d 598, 605-06 (2006) (stating the appellate court is free to decide the question based on its consideration of law, public policy, and the courtâ€™s sense of justice).Â  Notwithstanding, this court will accord the most respectful consideration to the interpretation of a statute by the agency charged with its administration.Â  Bursey v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 369 S.C. 176, ___, 631 S.E.2d 899, 905 (2006).
As to questions of fact in workersâ€™ compensation actions, this court reviews factual findings of the commission under the substantial evidence standard and may reverse a factual finding only if the finding is clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence on the whole record or is affected by error of law.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5) (Supp. 2006).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Smith Construction argues the commission erred by requiring a contractor to collect proof of insurance from its subcontractor for each job the subcontractor performs.Â  Smith Construction contends that a contractor complies with section 42-1-415 by obtaining proof of insurance from its subcontractor once a year.Â  We disagree.
Under section 42-1-415(A) a contractor may transfer liability to the Fund when its subcontractorâ€™s employee is injured if the contractor submitted â€œdocumentation to the commission that a . . . subcontractor has represented himself to a higher tier subcontractor, contractor, or project owner as having workersâ€™ compensation insurance at the time the . . . subcontractor was engaged to perform work.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-415(A) (Supp. 2006).
Smith Construction, relying on this courtâ€™s decision in South Carolina Uninsured Employerâ€™s Fund v. House, 360 S.C. 468, 602 S.E.2d 81 (Ct. App. 2004), contends the statute is satisfied if the contractor obtains proof of insurance the first time it hires a subcontractor in any given year regardless of the number or variety of jobs the subcontractor performs for the contractor throughout the year.Â  Hardee conversely argues House does not precisely address this issue and a common sense reading of the statute demands a contractor ask for proof of insurance at the beginning of each new job rather than once a year.Â  
We agree with Hardeeâ€™s interpretation of the statute.Â  In House, a subcontractor, â€œ[w]hen he was initially engaged to perform the work,â€ presented the contractor with proof of workersâ€™ compensation coverage from June 5, 1997 to June 5, 1998.Â  House, 360 S.C. at 469, 602 S.E.2d at 81.Â  When the original policy expired, the subcontractor provided a certificate indicating continuing coverage.Â  Id. at 469-70, 602 S.E.2d at 81.Â  The policyâ€™s history indicated several cancellations and reinstatements for nonpayment of premiums until March of 1999 when the insurer sent the subcontractor a notice of cancellation for refusal to pay the renewal premium.Â  Id. at 470, 602 S.E.2d at 81-82.Â  The subcontractor failed to pay the premiums necessary to reinstate the policy and was refused coverage by another carrier but continued to verbally advise the contractor that it had workersâ€™ compensation coverage.Â  Id. at 470, 602 S.E.2d at 82.
The issue presented in House was whether the contractor satisfied its obligation under section 42-1-415 when it requested a certificate of insurance at the beginning of the work or whether the contractor had a continuing duty to collect proof of insurance throughout the term of the work.Â  We found the contractor satisfied its burden under the statute by collecting proof of insurance â€œat the time the . . . subcontractor was engaged to perform work.â€Â  Id. at 471, 602 S.E.2d at 82 (quoting section 42-1-415(A)).Â  Further, we found that under 42-1-415(C) the subcontractor had a duty to notify the contractor of any lapse in coverage. Â Id. at 472, 602 S.E.2d at 83.Â  House does not address the situation presented here, where a contractor employs a subcontractor for a series of separate jobs in a single year.Â  However, the court in House concluded:Â  â€œThe statute does not require a prime contractor to continue collecting proof of its subcontractorâ€™s insurance coverage after the subcontractor is engaged to perform the work.â€ Â Id. (emphasis added).Â  Our reading of the House case leads us to conclude the work performed in House was on a continuous job rather than a series of separate jobs.Â  In this case, the work performed at the time of the injury was at a new job site, the Socastee project.Â  Accordingly, House does not control.
Turning to the statute, we find the plain language contemplates the contractor require proof of insurance for each job the subcontractor performsÂ  regardless of the number of jobs the subcontractor performs in a given year.Â  To qualify for reimbursement under section 42-1-415, the contractor must collect proof of insurance at the time the subcontractor â€œis engaged to perform work.â€ Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-415(B) (Supp. 2006).Â  We find the phrase â€œengaged to perform workâ€ refers to when a subcontractor begins work at a construction site.Â  The statute is plain and unambiguous and, therefore, it is not our place to change the meaning of the statute.Â  See Paschal v. State Election Commâ€™n, 317 S.C. 434, 436, 454 S.E.2d 890, 891 (1995) (finding that if a statuteâ€™s language is clear and unambiguous the rules of statutory construction are unnecessary and the court cannot impose another meaning).Â  If the state legislature had intended for a contractor to collect documentation of insurance from a subcontractor once a year, it could have drafted the statute to reflect that intent.Â  See Croft v. Old Republic Ins. Co., 365 S.C. 402, 413, 618 S.E.2d 909, 914 (2005) (considering legislatureâ€™s options in wording a statute when interpreting the statute).Â  We find some support from our sister state, North Carolina, in arriving at this interpretation.Â  See generally Spoone v. Newsome Chevrolet-Buick, 309 S.C. 432, 434, 424 S.E.2d 489, 490 (1992) (giving weight to North Carolina precedent in interpreting workersâ€™ compensation legislation); Robertson v. Hagood Homes, Inc., 584 S.E.2d 871, 878 (N.C. Ct. App. 2003) (interpreting the North Carolina statute requiring proof of insurance and concluding:Â  â€œHaving chosen voluntarily to sublet a series of individual contracts, [contractor was] required . . . to obtain a certificate for each separate contract.â€).
Having concluded the statute requires proof of insurance for each job, we review the factual findings of the commission under the substantial evidence standard.Â  The single commissioner found, and the commission concurred, that neither McDowell nor Smith Construction was aware the policy lapsed and that, although McDowell provided Smith Construction with proof of workersâ€™ compensation insurance for 2002, it did not provide a certificate of insurance for the Socastee project.Â  Accordingly, Smith Construction failed to comply with the statute.Â  We find no error in these findings.Â  We therefore agree with the commission that because Smith Construction failed to comply with the statutory provisions, it was not entitled to shift the burden of coverage to the Fund.Â  
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and SHORT, JJ., concur.
