description: Cedric Ali Colden appeals his conviction for kidnapping, armed robbery, and murder.  Colden argues the trial court erred in denying his motion for a continuance and refusing to order a mental competency evaluation.  We affirm.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


Â THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State Respondent,
v.
        Cedric A. Colden  Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Reginald I. Lloyd, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4207
Submitted February 1, 2007 â€“ Filed February 20, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, of Columbia; and Solicitor Barbara R. Morgan, of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Cedric Ali Colden appeals his conviction for kidnapping, armed robbery, and murder.Â  Colden argues the trial court erred in denying his motion for a continuance and refusing to order a mental competency evaluation.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On December 21, 2003, Cedric Ali Colden was involved in the kidnapping and armed robbery of Alexander Gorman, as well as the kidnapping, armed robbery, and murder of Christopher Carroll.Â  Colden was arrested and detained shortly thereafter.Â  
Coldenâ€™s trial was initially scheduled for Aiken Countyâ€™s September 7 and 14, 2004 terms of court.Â  Just before the trial was set to begin, in late August of that year, Colden changed lawyers.Â  He released his public defender and hired private counsel, who he believed â€œwould have the time to put into the case and focus on it and not be overloaded.â€
On September 7, the day the case was scheduled to be called, Coldenâ€™s recently retained attorneys moved for a continuance, relying primarily upon the fact they had become involved in the case only ten days earlier. Â Further, they indicated discovery motions had been recently filed and they did not know, at the present time, what evidence or witnesses would be involved in the trial.Â  The deputy solicitor stated that he would like to try the case during the October 18 term; however, Coldenâ€™s counsel responded that â€œgiven the seriousness of the case,â€ they felt four to five additional weeks was too short a time to allow for proper preparation.Â  The trial judge ordered the case carried over until the October 18 term, although subsequent discussions between the two sides would later move the case to the October 25 term of court.Â  
On October 6, Coldenâ€™s lawyers moved for another continuance, asking the case be set for December.Â  Emphasizing the severity of the charges against their client, Coldenâ€™s counsel argued they had not had sufficient time to prepare and noted they had not yet received or reviewed the police investigation notes regarding the case. Â Additionally, the attorneys inculcated that Colden had recently provided them with the name of an â€œexonerationâ€ witness whom they were uncertain they would be able to locate and interview within the next nineteen days. 
In response, the solicitor stressed that the date was originally set for the September term of court and Coldenâ€™s prior counsel, the assistant public defender, had been notified two terms prior that the case would be called at that time. Â He emphasized it was Colden who waited until late August to make the decision to retain new representation.Â  Additionally, the prosecutor indicated he would provide Colden with all discovery the State possessed. 
The judge denied the motion for a continuance.Â  However, he noted that if another issue material to the defense developed, particularly one involving the witness Colden had not yet located, he would consider changing his ruling.Â  Although they provided no new information, Coldenâ€™s attorneys renewed the motion for continuance at both the beginning and end of the trial.Â  The motions were denied.
During a motion hearing on October 6, Coldenâ€™s counsel moved for an order for a competency and criminal responsibility evaluation.Â  Coldenâ€™s lawyers declared: â€œOftentimes when we talk to Mr. Colden, he is not really responsive to the questions that we put to him.Â  He has a tendency sometimes to ramble on with things that are unrelated to our discussions.â€Â  The prosecution objected, asseverating they did not know of any reason why Colden should be evaluated.Â  
Colden was subject to voir dire by the judge.Â  The colloquy with the court included discussion about his family and childhood.Â  Colden provided rational responses regarding his age (thirty-three) and education (high school graduate).Â  He described and discussed his four years of service in the Navy, previous job at a fiberglass plant, and work selling automobiles.Â  
Mrs. Jennings, Coldenâ€™s maternal grandmother, took part in the voir dire.Â  After providing some brief information about her grandsonâ€™s family background, she testified she had not noticed Colden needed a doctor, although she had asked for someone, such as a minister, to speak with him.Â  Similarly, Ms. Dickerson, Coldenâ€™s girlfriend of four years, stated she had requested for a social worker to see Colden.Â  Dickerson believed, at the time he was first arrested, Colden had â€œa lot of angry feelings, probably family-wise, that should have been resolved years ago that werenâ€™t.â€Â  Colden informed the court that he had not received any mental counseling, but had participated in an Alcohol and Drug Safety Program in 1994 and completed an Alcoholics Anonymous class in 1995.Â  
Coldenâ€™s criminal record was discussed.Â  His only prior offenses were relatively minor, magistrate-level misdemeanors, handled without the assistance of counsel.Â  The judge covered the various actors within the trial setting.Â  Colden stated he understood the trial judge was there to â€œlisten to both partiesâ€™ sidesâ€ and the jury â€œbasically decide[d] whether youâ€™re guilty or not . . . .â€Â  He explained his lawyersâ€™ duty was to â€œrepresent [him] to the best of their ability.â€ Â When the judge elucidated the specific role of the solicitor as being the person who would present witnesses and evidence to try to convince the jury of his guilt, Colden replied that he comprehended.Â Â Â  
Colden advised the court that he was aware he was being charged with one count of murder and two counts of armed robbery and kidnapping.Â  He described armed robbery as â€œbasically robbing somebody . . . with a weapon and so forthâ€ and kidnapping as â€œabducting somebody.â€Â  Colden affirmed he understood the need to talk with his lawyers regarding witnesses and facts.Â  He stated he had not yet discussed with his attorneys what the state would have to prove at trial for him to be convicted. Â Colden reported he, â€œfor the most part,â€ understood the things his counsel and the court had gone over with him.Â  Â Â 
In support of their request, Coldenâ€™s attorneys vouched they had explained to their client the role of the judge, burdens of proof, and elements the solicitor would have to prove, and Coldenâ€™s inability to better discuss these issues with the judge left â€œno doubtâ€ a competency evaluation should be performed.Â  Counsel admitted to the court their clientâ€™s demeanor during the hearing was similar to what they had observed earlier, but added that at times Colden was â€œnot very responsive or would ramble on about something that may not be relevant to the questions that were asked.â€Â  They asked the court to look past his answers and consider his â€œherky, jerky movementâ€ and inability to know what to do with his hands.Â  Counsel conceded they felt Colden potentially understood what was happening, but felt the potential sentence of life without parole supported the need for the evaluation and should be made â€œout of a precaution.â€Â  
In response, the solicitor offered that during the judgeâ€™s questioning, Colden â€œanswered very rationally and thoughtfully and noted â€œhis ability to speak and his ability to enunciate and his ability to answer questions.â€Â  Although acknowledging he had no way of knowing if Colden suffered from any â€œun-surfaced mental illness,â€ he stated nothing in his investigation indicated its existence.Â  The solicitor opined that he detected a level of [mental] competenceâ€ in Colden and requested the evaluation be refused.Â  
The court determined Colden to be â€œa very articulate, intelligent young man,â€ and, noting his â€œgood grasp of dates and history,â€ found him â€œto be probably more lucid and articulately aware of his surroundings and proceedings against him than a number of defendants seen when this issue is raised.â€Â  The judge felt Colden maintained good eye contact, â€œseem[ed] fairly relaxed in answering questions about his past,â€ and appeared to be very forthright with court.Â  In conclusion, the court held:

I detected nothing here today that would, I believed, indicate the need for further evaluation or any evaluation.Â  I do certainly have a lot of respect for Mr. Simmons and Mr. Grant and their abilities as lawyers, but without something specific in terms of his behavior as well as his inability to assist you all, at this point especially, I do not believe I have before me - - Iâ€™m going to deny any of the [McNaughten] issues.Â  Again, I think the burden is on the defense to bring that forward.Â  At this point, that has not been brought forward.Â  It was not really argued to the court by counsel nor his grandmother and fiancÃ© raised anything in my questioning of them related to either issue, his competency at this time or anything in his past that might indicate some mental health issues.Â  There was just no indication at this point in time that would cause the court to inquire an evaluation.Â  

The motion for a mental evaluation was denied.
At the outset of the trial, prior to jury selection, Coldenâ€™s attorneys renewed their request for a competency evaluation.Â  This, as well as another re-assertion of the motion just before jury instructions, was refused.Â  In expounding upon his decision, the trial judge stated: 

The previous motion for a psychological evaluation was denied, and I stand by that ruling as well and, again, note that I do believe that based on the courtâ€™s interview of Mr. Colden a few weeks ago as well as his time in this courtroom during the course of this trial, I do not believe that any psychological evaluation was needed.Â  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
The granting of a motion for a continuance is within the sound discretion of the trial court and will not be disturbed absent a clear showing of an abuse of discretion. Â State v. Tanner, 299 S.C. 459, 462, 385 S.E.2d 832, 834 (1989); State v. Mansfield, 343 S.C. 66, 72, 537 S.E.2d 257, 260 (Ct. App. 2000); State v. White, 311 S.C. 289, 293, 428 S.E.2d 740, 742 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  Reversals for the denial of a continuance â€œare about as rare as the proverbial hensâ€™ teeth.â€Â  State v. McMillian, 349 S.C. 17, 21, 561 S.E.2d 602, 604 (2002) (citing State v. Lytchfield, 230 S.C. 405, 409, 95 S.E.2d 857, 859, (1957)).
The ordering of a competency examination is within the discretion of the trial judge.Â  State v. Drayton, 270 S.C. 582, 584, 243 S.E.2d 458, 459 (1978); State v. Singleton, 322 S.C. 480, 483, 472 S.E.2d 640, 642 (Ct. App. 1996). Â The refusal to grant such an examination will not be disturbed on appeal absent a clear showing of an abuse of that discretion.Â  Drayton, 270 S.C. at 584, 243 S.E.2d at 459; State v. Buchanan, 302 S.C. 83, 85, 394 S.E.2d 1, 2 (Ct. App. 1990).Â  â€œThis is so, because the determination of whether there is â€˜reason to believeâ€™ a defendant lacks a certain mental capacity necessarily requires the exercise of discretion.Â  State v. White, 364 S.C. 143, 147-48, 611 S.E.2d 927, 929 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing and quoting State v. Bradshaw, 269 S.C. 642, 644, 239 S.E.2d 652, 653 (1977)).
An abuse of discretion occurs when the conclusions of the trial court either lack evidentiary support or are controlled by an error of law.Â  State v. Irick, 344 S.C. 460, 464, 545 S.E.2d 282, 284 (2001); State v. Funderburk, 367 S.C. 236, 239, 625 S.E.2d 248, 249-50 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  If there is any evidence to support the trial judge's decision, the appellate courts will affirm it. Â State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 7, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001); State v. Taylor, 360 S.C. 18, 598 S.E.2d 735 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Even without any evidentiary support, â€œ[i]n order for an error to warrant reversal, the error must result in prejudice to the appellant.â€Â  State v. Preslar, 364 S.C. 466, 473, 613 S.E.2d 381, 385 (Ct. App. 2005); see also State v. Beck, 342 S.C. 129, 536 S.E.2d 679 (2000); State v. Wyatt, 317 S.C. 370, 453 S.E.2d 890 (1995) (error without prejudice does not warrant reversal).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
A. Continuance
Colden argues the trial court abused its discretion by rejecting his motion for a continuance. Â He alleges his guarantee of effective assistance of counsel required the continuance because his attorneys: (1) were retained approximately two months prior to trial; (2) only recently learned of a potential â€œexonerationâ€ witness they had not yet been able to locate; (3) did not have ample opportunity to interview witnesses; and (4) had not received or reviewed the stateâ€™s evidence or â€œcriticalâ€ police investigation notes.Â  We disagree.Â  
The South Carolina Rules of Criminal Procedure state:

No motion for continuance of trial shall be granted on account of the absence of a witness without the oath of the party, his counsel, or agent to the following effect: the testimony of the witness is material to the support of the action or defense of the party moving; the motion is not intended for delay, but is made solely because he cannot go safely to trial without such testimony; and has made use of due diligence to procure the testimony of the witness or of such other circumstances as will satisfy the court that his motion is not intended for delay.
(1) When a subpoena has been issued, the original shall be produced with proof of service or the reason why not served endorsed thereon or attached thereto; or if lost the same proof shall be offered with additional proof of the loss of the original subpoena.
(2) A party applying for such postponement on account of the absence of a witness shall set forth under oath in addition to the foregoing matter what fact or facts he believes the witness if present would testify to and the grounds for such belief.

Rule 7(b), SCRCrimP.Â  
The granting or denial of a motion for a continuance is within the sound discretion of the trial judge.Â  State v. Babb, 299 S.C. 451, 454, 385 S.E.2d 827, 829 (1989) (citing State v. Dingle, 279 S.C. 278, 306 S.E.2d 223 (1983)).Â  Our appellate courts have shown great deference to trial judges in this matter.Â  See State v. Nicholson, 366 S.C. 568, 623 S.E.2d 100 (Ct. App. 2005) (no abuse of discretion in denial of alternate motion for a continuance to obtain new expert witness on characteristics of sexual abuse victim after the state, shortly before trial, gave notice to defense â€œas a professional courtesyâ€ where it was not required to provide the information either under Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83, 83 S.Ct. 1194 (1963) or Rule 5, SCRCrimP); State v. Asbury, 328 S.C. 187, 493 S.E.2d 349 (1997) (finding no abuse in denying a continuance in a second trial where the first trial transcript would be beneficial, but not essential, and where backup tapes were available and could have been used for impeachment purposes; but see McMillian, 349 S.C. 17, 561 S.E.2d 602 (holding the trial judge abused his discretion in denying a continuance request to obtain a transcript of first trial to use in impeaching a witness where retrial occurred only two weeks later, no backup tapes were available, and the credibility of the â€œretrialâ€ witness was shown to be crucial). 
In State v. McKennedy, 348 S.C. 270, 559 S.E.2d 850 (2002), our Supreme Court found the defendant was not entitled to a continuance. Â Like the present case, the defendant merely referred to a neighbor he hoped to interview, but did not name the witness or indicate how that witness would be beneficial to his case.Â  McKennedy, who had less than one month to prepare for trial, argued he may have been able to produce additional witnesses, but could not make a specific showing of how any additional time would have been beneficial to his case.Â  The Supreme Court took note that it â€œhas repeatedly upheld denials of motions for continuances where there was no showing that any other evidence on behalf of the defendant could have been introduced, or that other points could have been raised, if more time had been granted to prepare for trial.â€Â  McKennedy, 348 S.C. at 280, 559 S.E.2d at 885 (citing State v. Williams, 321 S.C. 455, 459, 469, S.E.2d 49, 51 (1996)).Â  
The court, in Skeen v. State, 325 S.C. 210, 481 S.E.2d 129 (1997), looked at defense counselâ€™s failure to request a continuance.Â  It determined there was no error because there was no evidence presented that additional time to prepare would have made any possible impact on the result.Â  In that case, counsel declared he would have liked to have consulted with his own medical expert to help him prepare for the cross-examination of a witness for the state, but could not suggest how this would have ultimately made any difference.Â  The court noted its reliance upon Bozeman v. State, 307 S.C. 172, 414 S.E.2d 144 (1992), and State v. Motley, 251 S.C. 568, 164 S.E.2d 569 (1968), where it found â€œno reversible error because the petitioner did not point to any other evidence or witnesses which could have been produced if a continuance had been granted.â€Â  Skeen, 325 S.C. at 214, 481 S.E.2d at 132; see also State v. Register, 323 S.C. 471, 482, 476 S.E.2d 153, 160 (1996) (no abuse of discretion in denying a continuance where counsel waited until one month prior to trial to investigate DNA evidence).
Regarding the issue of the â€œexonerationâ€ witness, whose existence Coldenâ€™s counsel claimed at the October 6 hearing to have only recently been made aware, the record is silent as to whether they were still pursuing this witness at the time of the trial.Â  Despite the fact the judge expressly left the door open for reconsideration of the request for a continuance for the lack of this witness, at no time during the motions to continue, both before and at the conclusion of the trial, did Colden expressly state the name or need for this or any other witness.Â  His attorneysâ€™ concern about the witness was inadequate to support a motion for a continuance.Â  All components of Rule 7(b), SCRCrimP, including that of the attestation under oath, are strictly required, and a party asking for a continuance must show due diligence in trying to procure the testimony of the witness, as well as what the party believes the absent witness would testify to and the basis for that belief.Â  See State v. White, 311 S.C. 289, 292, 428 S.E.2d 740, 742 (Ct. App. 1993) (holding a continuance was not required where there was no compliance with Rule 7(b), SCRCrimP after an expert witness unexpectedly went on vacation and neither the defendant nor counsel offered under oath what facts they believed the absent witness would have testified, the grounds for that belief, that the continuance not intended to delay, or that due diligence was used in their efforts to make the witness available).Â  It is paramount that the party asking for the continuance show â€œdue diligenceâ€ was used in trying to procure the absent witness.Â  See State v. Yarborough, 363 S.C. 260, 266, 609 S.E.2d 592, 595-96 (Ct. App. 2005) (witnessâ€™s sudden decision not to cooperate did not mandate a continuance where no evidentiary hearing was necessary and, alternatively, where due diligence in asserting an attempt to acquire affidavits was not shown).Â  Not only was there no showing that by the time of trial counsel had been unable to locate the unnamed witness, but it is evident that the requirements of Rule 7(b) were never satisfied.
The record reveals Coldenâ€™s counsel had adequate time to investigate.Â  As the court noted at the very outset of the trial, the case had previously been continued from two earlier start dates.Â  Coldenâ€™s trial attorneys were hired on August 28, ten days before the September 7 motion hearing.Â  At that time, the public defenderâ€™s office had participated in a preliminary hearing on July 7.Â  A transcript of the hearing had been filed in the clerk of courtâ€™s office on July 16.Â  During this proceeding, Coldenâ€™s attorneys complained that the police report had not been received.Â  This record was thoroughly reviewed at the hearing and essentially revealed the entirety of the stateâ€™s case ultimately presented at trial.Â  Furthermore, the trial did not begin until October 27, nearly two months after Coldenâ€™s counsel had been retained.Â  
A plethora of pre-trial motions reveals the depth of the attorneysâ€™ understanding of the nature of both the Stateâ€™s and defenseâ€™s cases, and the opening statement reveals a strong knowledge of the prosecutionâ€™s strategy. During trial, Coldenâ€™s attorneys presented a number of complicated and detailed motions and objections that, in order to make, required a thorough understanding of the case and a familiarity with the police investigation notes.Â  Their request for the jury to view the crime scene rather than rely on a video representation shows a strong grasp of the facts of the case.Â  The trial court noted: â€œColden has been represented more than ably by two very experienced and two very good attorneys. Yâ€™all did a very good job in defending Mr. Colden.â€Â  Thus, the lawyersâ€™ very performance further eviscerates the argument that Colden was denied effective assistance of counsel.Â  The request for a continuance lacked foundation.Â  
B. Competency Evaluation / Competency to Stand Trial
Colden contends the trial court erred in denying his attorneysâ€™ request that a mental examination for competency to stand trial be ordered.Â  Because his attorneys opined their conversations with him â€œhad been disjointed and confused,â€ that there had been difficulty communicating with him, and that he frequently gave non-responsive answers and â€œrambled on,â€ Colden asserts he was entitled to the evaluation. Â He takes the position that the â€œdefense counselâ€™s representations alone should have invoked S.C. Â§ 44-23-410â€ because, due to their â€œfrequent conversation and interactionâ€ with him, the attorneys were in a unique and better position to evaluate his ability to assist them with his case.Â  He opines their concern about his capacity was supported by the uncharacteristic nature of the charge since he had a relatively clean record until he was thirty-three years old.Â  Finally, he avers that since the issue was raised â€œwell before trialâ€ (three weeks prior), the prosecution would not have suffered any harm had the evaluation been ordered, and it was therefore an abuse of discretion to deny the request.Â  We disagree.
â€œDue process of law prohibits the conviction of a person who is mentally incompetent.â€Â  Jeter v. State, 308 S.C. 230, 232, 417 S.E.2d 594, 595 (1992) (citing Bishop v. United States, 350 U.S. 961, 76 S.Ct. 440 (1956)); State v. Singleton, 322 S.C. 480, 482, 472 S.E.2d 640, 641 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  South Carolina law provides:

Whenever a judge . . . has reason to believe that a person on trial before him, charged with the commission of a criminal offense or civil contempt, is not fit to stand trial because the person lacks the capacity to understand the proceedings against him or to assist in his own defense as a result of a lack of mental capacity, the judge shall: 
(1) Order examination of such person by two examiners designated by the Department of Mental Health or the Mental Retardation Department or both . . . . 

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-23-410 (2002).Â  Thus, if the judge believes the person may be unfit to stand trial, a competency evaluation is compulsory.Â  See State v. Locklair, 341 S.C. 352, 535 S.E.2d 420 (2000) (finding the trial judge correctly ordered a competency evaluation where he felt the mental condition of the defendant might be called into question at trial and the defense stated it intended to offer expert testimony that the defendant suffered from a mental condition).Â  However, great deference is given to trial judge who sits in a better position to ascertain the defendantâ€™s faculties. Â See State v. Weik, 356 S.C. 76, 587 S.E.2d 683 (2002) (holding the court did not err in refusing to order a second competency evaluation where deference was given to the trial judge who was able to view the appellantâ€™s demeanor); State v. Kelly, 331 S.C. 132, 502 S.E.2d 99 (1998); State v. Bell, 293 S.C. 391 360 S.E.2d 706 (1987).
In State v. Burgess, 356 S.C. 572, 590 S.E.2d 42 (Ct. App. 2003), this court identified three factors to be considered in determining whether further inquiry into a defendantsâ€™ fitness to stand trial was warranted.Â  These are: (1) evidence of irrational behavior; (2) demeanor at trial; and (3) prior medical opinion regarding ability to stand trial. Â In some instances, the presence of just one of the factors may justify further inquiry requiring a mental evaluation.Â  In Burgess, the defendantâ€™s demeanor during the motion was very appropriate and at the hearing she understood the proceedings, the roles of the various trial participants, and the charges leveled against her.Â  â€œBeyond counselâ€™s statements regarding his inability to talk intelligently with Burgess and his opinion that she could not assist in her defense, counsel offered nothing to demonstrate that Burgessâ€™s mental retardation was such as to render her unfit for trial.â€Â  Burgess, 356 S.C. at 576, 590 S.E.2d at 44.Â  This court noted the trial judge did not experience any difficulty in conversing with Burgess and her testimony at a Jackson v. Denno hearing â€œseem[ed] to undercut any question of her competency.â€Â  Id.
This case has great similarities to the situation in Burgess. Â The reasoning behind the competency request did not rely upon any pre-existing history of mental illness (although in Burgess the defendant was mentally handicapped), but was instead based upon a perceived difficulty counsel faced in discussing matters with their client.Â  Coldenâ€™s voir dire conclusively revealed his ability to answer questions rationally, appropriately, and on point.Â  He demonstrated a manifest understanding of the proceedings, the roles of the various participants, and the charges he was facing.Â  Coldenâ€™s counsel offered nothing to demonstrate that his mental state was such as to render him unfit for trial.Â  As in Burgess, the courtâ€™s questioning of Colden in the pre-trial voir dire, his examination during a Jackson v. Denno hearing, and the courtâ€™s inquiry during the waiver of his right to testify, indicated that Colden had no difficulty conversing effectively.Â  Similarly, pre-existing evidence of the audiotaped statement of Colden did not raise any mental health concerns.Â  Finally, the trial courtâ€™s assessment of Coldenâ€™s demeanor throughout the trial was supportive of the courtâ€™s conclusion that the evaluation was not required.
There was no evidence of irrational behavior before or during the trial, nor prior medical opinion concerning competency as to require an evaluation under the Burgess factors.Â  Both after the hearing at the outset of the trial and at the close of the evidence, the trial judge specifically articulated that he saw nothing to indicate a need for an evaluation or any indication of a mental issue, past or present. Â Pellucidly, a review of the record and circumstances brings us to the ineluctable conclusion that the trial judge did not abuse his discretion in denying the motion.Â  
CONCLUSION 
The trial judge did not abuse his discretion in denying Coldenâ€™s motion for a continuance.Â  This denial was supported by the facts and mandated by the law. Â Absent any showing of the existence of a mental illness, the court properly denied Coldenâ€™s counselâ€™s request for a mental examination for competency to stand trial.Â  Accordingly, Coldenâ€™s convictions are
AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE and SHORT, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Joseph H. Moore, Appellant,
v.
M. M. Weinberg, Jr. and Weinberg and Brown,
L.L.P. Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Â Diane S. Goodstein, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4209
Submitted February 1, 2007 â€“ Filed February 20, 2007

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED


  
    
      
A. Camden Lewis, Peter D. Protopapas and Brady R. Thomas, all of Columbia, for Appellant.
Harry C. Wilson, Jr. and David C. Holler, both of Sumter, for Respondents.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.: Joseph Moore (Moore) appeals the grant of summary judgment with regard to his claims of negligence, conversion, and civil conspiracy against M. M. Weinberg, Jr. and Weinberg and Brown, L.L.P. (collectively Weinberg).Â  The trial court granted Weinbergâ€™s summary judgment motion based on the doctrine of novation.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.[1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In the late 1980s, Clarence Wheeler and Joseph Moore entered into a business relationship where Wheeler placed video-poker machines in Mooreâ€™s service stations.Â  Moore loaned Wheeler small amounts of money on a yearly basis for business expenses, such as buying video-poker machines and licenses.Â  Frequently, Moore and Wheeler either renegotiated these loans, or Wheeler paid the outstanding balance and he and Moore arranged a new loan. 
In November 1999, Wheeler executed a note to Moore in the amount of $92,000. Â The note provided for a built-in premium of $12,000.Â  From the $92,000, Moore gave Wheeler $80,000 and kept the $12,000 premium. Â In order to secure his obligation, Wheeler assigned Moore $80,000, to be deducted from the anticipated proceeds from litigation over the sale of Wheelerâ€™s music business.Â  An escrow account containing $100,000 was held by the Clarendon County Clerk of Court pending the outcome of Wheelerâ€™s litigation. Â On November 18, 1999, Wheelerâ€™s attorney, M. M. Weinberg, Jr., the same attorney representing him in the litigation, prepared the Assignment, that provided, in part:

Clarence Wheeler does by this instrument assign to Joseph Moore so much of any recovery that he may make from the debt owed to him by A&E, Inc. and the escrow account, which is pending as a result of said litigation, unto said Joseph Moore, his heirs and assigns to completely satisfy said debt.Â  
This assignment shall be and is to the extent of the money owed at the time of the execution of the assignment. 

Wheeler settled the litigation and was to receive the $100,000 from the escrow account.Â  The opposing party was to receive the $10,829.16 in interest the account had accrued.Â  When Clarendon County Clerk of Court transferred the funds from the escrow account to Weinberg, he disbursed $74,458.24 to Wheeler, paid $520 to Wheelerâ€™s former secretary, and retained $25,000 as his attorneyâ€™s fee.[2]Â  In executing these disbursements Weinberg forgot or â€œoverlooked [the] Assignment.â€Â  
After receiving the settlement money from Weinberg, Wheeler tendered $50,000 to Mooreâ€™s son in payment of the debt.Â  Moore was out of town at the time.Â  Subsequently, Moore notified Wheeler that he had not fully satisfied his loan obligation.Â  In June, 2002, Moore and Wheeler added a handwritten note at the end of the 1999 original: â€œI Clarence Wheeler agree that I owe Joseph H. Moore $80,000.00 since March 17, 2000 and agree to pay him 6% [i]nterest on the $80,000.00 balance.Â  Clarence Wheeler payed [sic] $50,000 on July 19, 2002.â€Â  Both Moore and Wheeler signed the addition to the note.Â  
In October 2002, attorney John Land contacted Weinberg by telephone on Mooreâ€™s behalf concerning the release of the assigned funds.[3]Â  Weinberg agreed to consult with Wheeler and respond to Mooreâ€™s demand for payment of Wheelerâ€™s outstanding obligation.Â  After receiving no response, Land informed Weinberg by letter, dated October 14, 2002, that Moore had an absolute security in the released funds through the Assignment and would not relieve Wheeler of his remaining indebtedness.
On April 15, 2003, Moore initiated this action against Weinberg, alleging negligence, conversion, and civil conspiracy.Â  Weinberg answered and asserted, inter alia, a defense based on the doctrine of novation.Â  Both Moore and Weinberg filed motions for summary judgment.Â  The trial court granted Weinbergâ€™s motion for summary judgment, finding the handwritten addendum to the 1999 original note constituted a novation, thus relieving Weinberg of any duty he may have owed Moore.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn reviewing the grant of summary judgment, [an appellate court] applies the same standard that governs the trial court under Rule 56, SCRCP: summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.â€ Â Pittman v. Grand Strand Entmâ€™t, Inc., 363 S.C. 531, 536, 611 S.E.2d 922, 925 (2005); Eagle Container Co., LLC v. County of Newberry, 366 S.C. 611, 622 S.E.2d 733 (Ct. App. 2005); B & B Liquors, Inc. v. Oâ€™Neil, 361 S.C. 267, 603 S.E.2d 629 (Ct. App. 2004). Â In determining whether any triable issue of fact exists, the evidence and all inferences that can reasonably be drawn therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party. Â Medical Univ. of South Carolina v. Arnaud, 360 S.C. 615, 602 S.E.2d 747 (2004); Rife v. Hitachi Constr. Mach. Co., Ltd., 363 S.C. 209, 609 S.E.2d 565 (Ct. App. 2005). Â If triable issues exist, those issues must go to the jury. Â Mulherin-Howell v. Cobb, 362 S.C. 588, 608 S.E.2d 587 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  
Summary judgment is appropriate if the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Helms Realty, Inc. v. Gibson-Wall Co., 363 S.C. 334, 611 S.E.2d 485 (2005); BPS, Inc. v. Worthy, 362 S.C. 319, 608 S.E.2d 155 (Ct. App. 2005). Â On appeal from an order granting summary judgment, the appellate court will review all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most favorable to the non-moving party. Â Willis v. Wu, 362 S.C. 146, 607 S.E.2d 63 (2004); see also Schmidt v. Courtney, 357 S.C. 310, 592 S.E.2d 326 (Ct. App. 2003) (stating that all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising from the evidence must be construed most strongly against the moving party).
Summary judgment is not appropriate where further inquiry into the facts of the case is desirable to clarify the application of the law. Â Gadson v. Hembree, 364 S.C. 316, 613 S.E.2d 533 (2005); Montgomery v. CSX Transp., Inc., 362 S.C. 529, 608 S.E.2d 440 (Ct. App. 2004). Â Even when there is no dispute as to evidentiary facts, but only as to the conclusions or inferences to be drawn from them, summary judgment should be denied. Â Baugus v. Wessinger, 303 S.C. 412, 401 S.E.2d 169 (1991); Nelson v. Charleston County Parks & Recreation Commâ€™n, 362 S.C. 1, 605 S.E.2d 744 (Ct. App. 2004). Â When reasonable minds cannot differ on plain, palpable, and indisputable facts, summary judgment should be granted. Â Ellis v. Davidson, 358 S.C. 509, 595 S.E.2d 817 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The party seeking summary judgment has the burden of clearly establishing the absence of a genuine issue of material fact.Â  McCall v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 359 S.C. 372, 597 S.E.2d 181 (Ct. App. 2004). Â Once the party moving for summary judgment meets the initial burden of showing an absence of evidentiary support for the opponentâ€™s case, the opponent cannot simply rest on mere allegations or denials contained in the pleadings. Â Regions Bank v. Schmauch, 354 S.C. 648, 582 S.E.2d 432 (Ct. App. 2003). Â The nonmoving party must come forward with specific facts showing there is a genuine issue for trial. Â Rife, 363 S.C. at 214, 609 S.E.2d at 568.
â€œThe purpose of summary judgment is to expedite the disposition of cases which do not require the services of a fact finder.â€Â  Dawkins v. Fields, 354 S.C. 58, 69, 580 S.E.2d 433, 438 (2003) (quoting George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874 (2001)); Rumpf v. Massachusetts Mut. Life Ins. Co., 357 S.C. 386, 593 S.E.2d 183 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Summary judgment is a drastic remedy and should be cautiously invoked to ensure that a litigant is not improperly deprived of a trial on disputed factual issues. Â Helena Chem. Co. v. Allianz Underwriters Ins. Co., 357 S.C. 631, 594 S.E.2d 455 (2004); Hawkins v. City of Greenville, 358 S.C. 280, 594 S.E.2d 557 (Ct. App. 2004).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Novation
Moore argues the trial court erred in granting summary judgment based on novation as a defense to negligence, conversion, and civil conspiracy claims.Â  We agree.
Novation is a defense to contract claims.Â  â€œA novation is an agreement between all parties concerned for the substitution of a new obligation between the parties with the intent to extinguish the old obligation.â€ Â Wayne Dalton Corp. v. Acme Doors, Inc., 302 S.C. 93, 96, 394 S.E.2d 5, 7 (Ct. App. 1990) (citing Ophuls & Hill Inc. v. Carolina Ice & Fuel Co., 160 S.C. 441, 158 S.E. 824 (1931)). There must be an intention to create a
novation.  Adams v. B & D, Inc., 297 S.C. 416, 377 S.E.2d 315 (1989). Â There can be no novation unless both parties so intend. Â Id. Â The party asserting a novation has the burden of proving
it. Â Superior Auto. Ins. Co. v. Maners, 261 S.C. 257, 199 S.E.2d 719 (1973).Â  â€œThe circumstances attending the transaction alleged to be a
novation must show the intention to substitute a new obligation in place of the existing one.â€Â  Wellman, Inc. v. Square D Co., 366 S.C. 61, 72, 620 S.E.2d 86, 92 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  An addendum that modifies a pre-existing agreement, but does not extinguish it, is not a novation. Â Parker v. Shecut, 340 S.C. 460, 531 S.E.2d 546 (Ct. App. 2000), revâ€™d on other grounds 349 S.C. 226, 562 S.E.2d 620 (2002).
In order to effectuate a novation by the substitution of a new obligation, both contracting parties must consent that the new agreement is to replace the old one and their consent must be apparent.Â  See Superior, 261 S.C. at 263, and 199 S.E.2d at 722 (finding language appearing on the face of the â€œModifying Agreementâ€ was clear and unambiguous and negated an intention for there to be a novation). Â If only the debtor intends that the existing contract should be discharged by the new agreement, there is no novation; the creditor must concur.
A novation may be broadly defined as a substitution of a new obligation for an old one, thereby extinguishing the old debt.Â  More specifically, novation is the substitution by mutual agreement of one debtor or one creditor for another, whereby the old debt is extinguished.Â  It is a mode of extinguishing one obligation by creating another; the substitution, not of a new paper or note, but of a new obligation in lieu of an old one, with the effect of paying, dissolving, or otherwise discharging it.Â  
Consequently, a novation may be accomplished in three ways:

(1)Â  By the substitution of a new obligation between the same parties,
with intent to extinguish the old obligation;
(2)Â  By the substitution of a new debtor in the place of the old one, with
intent to release the latter;
(3)Â  By the substitution of a new creditor in the place of an old one,
with intent to transfer the rights of the latter to the former.Â Â Â  

While Moore may have a cause of action in contract against Wheeler, his causes of action for conversion, negligence, and civil conspiracy against Weinberg sound in tort.Â  Tort causes of action are not transformed into actions in contract simply because they arise out of circumstances involving a contract.Â  As a matter of law, the trial court erred in granting summary judgment on the ground of novation.
Moore maintains that, even if novation were an applicable defense, the trial court erred in granting Weinberg summary judgment on novation when the trial court itself noted material issues of fact in dispute. Â Because we determine novation is not a defense in the case sub judice, we need not consider this issue. Â Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 518 S.E.2d 591 (1999) (holding an appellate court need not review remaining issues when its determination of a prior issue is dispositive of the appeal).
II.Â  Assignment
An assignment is the act of transferring to another all or part of oneâ€™s property, interest, or rights.Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 119 (6th ed. 1992). Â It includes transfers of all kinds of property, including negotiable instruments.Â  Id.Â  The assignment of an account involves the transfer to the assignee the right to have money, when collected, applied to the payment of his debt. Â Id.Â  The interest in the property assigned can be present, future, or contingent; it may represent contract rights to money, property, or performance, or rights to causes of action.Â  5 S.C. Jur. Assignments Â§ 2 (2006).
Three elements constitute an assignment: (1) an assignor; (2) an assignee; and (3) transfer of control of the thing assigned from the assignor to the assignee.Â  Donahue v. Multimedia, Inc., 362 S.C. 331, 338, 608 S.E.2d 162, 165 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing Leon v. Martinez, 638 N.E.2d 511 (N.Y. 1994)).Â  â€œAn assignment of a right is a manifestation of the assignorâ€™s intention to transfer it by virtue of which the assignorâ€™s right to performance by the obligor is extinguished in whole or in part and the assignee acquires a right to such performance.â€Â  Restatement (Second) of Contracts Â§ 317(1) (1981). Â South Carolina jurisprudence has long recognized that a chose in action can be validly assigned in either law or equity.Â  Slater Corp. v. S.C. Tax Commâ€™n, 280 S.C. 584, 587, 314 S.E.2d 31, 33 (Ct. App. 1984) (citing Forrest v. Warrington, 2 S.C. Eq. 254 (2 Des. Eq. 1804)); see also S.C. Jur. Assignments Â§ 19 (2006) (â€œA chose in action is the right of proceeding in a court to procure the payment of a sum of money, or the right to recover a personal chattel or a sum of money by action . . . . Â In South Carolina a chose or thing in action is statutorily included in oneâ€™s personal property and is assignable.â€).
An assignee stands in the shoes of its assignor. Â Twelfth RMA Partners, L.P. v. Natâ€™l Safe Corp., 335 S.C. 635, 639-40, 518 S.E.2d 44, 46 (Ct. App. 1999) (â€œ[T]he assignee should have all the same rights and privileges, including the right to sue . . . Â as the assignor.â€).Â  
In the present case, Wheeler assigned his right in the litigation proceeds and escrow account to Moore, thus giving Moore the right to the funds in payment of the debt Wheeler owed. Â At the conclusion of the litigation, the Clarendon County Clerk of Court transferred the funds held in escrow to Weinbergâ€™s trust account. Â He disbursed the funds to Wheeler. Â The Assignment, however, directed Weinberg to pay Moore the outstanding balance of Wheelerâ€™s debt from the assigned funds rather than releasing the funds to Wheeler.Â  
Moore asserts the trial court erred in granting the motion for summary judgment because he presented evidence sufficient to prove all the elements for each of his three causes of action against Weinberg: (1) negligence; (2) conversion; and (3) civil conspiracy.Â  As to negligence and conversion we agree.Â  As to civil conspiracy, we disagree.
A. Â Negligence
In order to prevail in a negligence cause of action, the plaintiff must establish: (1) the defendant owed a duty of care to the plaintiff; (2) the defendant breached the duty by a negligent act or omission; (3) the defendantâ€™s breach was the actual and proximate cause of the plaintiffâ€™s injury; and (4) the plaintiff suffered an injury or damages.Â  Steinke v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing & Regulation, 336 S.C. 373, 387, 520 S.E.2d 142, 149 (1999); see also Thomasko v. Poole, 349 S.C. 7, 561 S.E.2d 597 (2002).Â  â€œAn essential element in a cause of action for negligence is the existence of a legal duty of care owed by the defendant to the plaintiff. Â Without a duty, there is no actionable negligence.â€ Â Bishop v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Mental Health, 331 S.C. 79, 86, 502 S.E.2d 78, 81 (1998) (citing Rogers v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Parole &
Cmty. Corr., 320 S.C. 253, 464 S.E.2d 330 (1995)). 
Â â€œThe issue of negligence is a mixed question of law and fact.â€Â  Miller v. City of Camden, 317 S.C. 28, 31, 451 S.E.2d 401, 403 (Ct. App. 1994), affâ€™d as modified, 329 S.C. 310, 494 S.E.2d 813 (1997). Â First, the court must determine, as a matter of law, whether the law recognizes a particular duty. Â Ellis v. Niles, 324 S.C. 223, 479 S.E.2d 47 (1996). Â If there is no duty, the defendant is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law. Â Id.Â  If a duty does exist, the jury then determines whether a breach of the duty that resulted in damages occurred.Â  Miller, 317 S.C. at 31, 451 S.E.2d at 403; see also Creighton v. Coligny Plaza Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 334 S.C. 96, 512 S.E.2d 510 (Ct. App. 1998).
Generally, duty is defined as the obligation to conform to a particular standard of conduct toward another. Â Murray v. Bank of America, N.A.
  354 S.C. 337, 343, 580 S.E.2d 194, 197 (Ct. App. 2003) (citing Shipes v. Piggly Wiggly St. Andrews, Inc., 269 S.C. 479, 483, 238 S.E.2d 167, 168 (1977)).Â  
Our search of South Carolina jurisprudence reveals the issues presented in this case are novel.Â  However, many other jurisdictions have established that attorneys owe a duty to third parties in factually congeneric circumstances.Â  
The Idaho Court of Appeals has determined that from the outset of the attorney-client relationship, a law firm is obliged to disburse, and the client has a right to receive, any funds that he is entitled to. Â Bonanza Motors, Inc. v. Webb, 657 P.2d 1102, 1104 (Idaho App. 1983). Â Moreover, the clientâ€™s right to the future performance of the law firmâ€™s obligation may be assigned.Â  Id. (citing Restatement (Second) of Contracts Â§ 321(1) (1979); 3 S. Williston, A Treatise on the Law of Contracts Â§ 413 (3d ed. 1960)). Â The fact that the performance of this obligation occurs later, when proceeds of the lawsuit arrive, does not defeat an assignment.Â  Id. Â Nor is an assignment defeated by the fact that the clientâ€™s right to receive money was conditioned upon the availability of proceeds from the action against the insurance company. Â Id.Â  An adequately identified conditional right may be subject to assignment. Â Id. (citing Restatement Â§ 320; 4 A. Corbin, Corbin on Contracts Â§ 874 (1951)).Â  
The Idaho court emphasized:

Notice of an assignment puts the obligor on guard. Â The obligor is liable to the assignee if the funds assigned are subsequently paid to the assignor in violation of the assignment. Â Once a valid assignment has been made, the assignor cannot cancel or modify the assignment by unilateral action without the assent of the assignee; nor may he defeat the rights of the assignee. 

Id. (citing Wymer v. Wymer, 16 B.R. 497 (B.A.P. 9th Cir. 1980); Shore v. Shore, 139 Cal. Rptr. 349 (Cal. Dist. Ct. App. 1977); Chapman v. Tyler Bank & Trust Co., 396 S.W.2d 143 (Tex. Civ. App. 1965); 4 A. Corbin Â§ 890) (emphasis added). 
Similarly, in Brinkman v. Moskowitz,238 N.Y.S.2d 876, 876-77 (N.Y. App. Term. 1962), the court held where an attorney had notice of the assignment of a portion of the proceeds
of his clientâ€™s claim for personal injuries to the plaintiff, the attorney was liable to plaintiff for the resulting damage in distributing the proceeds without regard to the assignment.Â  Moreover, the Nevada Supreme Court determined that when a client assigns rights to the proceeds of a tort action to a creditor, those proceeds no longer belong to the client and an attorney is not obligated to pay those funds to his client. Â Achrem v. Expressway Plaza Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 917 P.2d 447, 450 (Nev. 1996) (citing Bonanza Motors,657 P.2d at 1104; Romero v. Earl, 810 P.2d 808 (N.M. 1991); Leon v. Martinez, 638 N.E.2d 511, 514 (N.Y. 1994); Aiello v. Levine, 255 N.Y.S.2d 921 (N.Y. App. Div. 1965); Brinkman, 238 N.Y.S.2d at 876-77).Â  In addition, the Nevada Supreme Court concluded that if a conflict exists between the clientâ€™s interests and the creditorâ€™s interests, the attorney should deposit the settlement proceeds in a trust fund account and request a court to direct the fundâ€™s distribution.Â  Achrem,917 P.2d at 450. Â Â 
The Ohio Court of Appeals found a client who made a valid assignment of part of his right to settlement proceeds was no longer entitled to receive the full amount of the settlement. Â Hsu v. Parker, 688 N.E.2d 1099 (Ohio Ct. App. 1996).Â  â€œAfter notice of the assignment has been given to the obligor, or knowledge thereof received by him in any manner, the assignor has no remaining power of release.Â  The obligor must pay the assignee.â€ Â Id. at 1102 (quoting 4 A. Corbin Â§ 890).Â  See also Berkowitz v. Haigood, 606 A.2d 1157, 1160 (N.J. Super. Ct. Law Div. 1992) (â€œSince the client has the power to validly assign the proceeds, the attorney has the obligation to honor such an assignment, if properly notified. Â The attorney does not violate the [Rules of Professional Conduct] because the funds in his trust account no longer belong to his client. Â The funds belong to the assignee of the client and, therefore, the client is not entitled to receive them under RPC 1.15(b).â€).
The South Carolina Supreme Court has recognized the relevance and admissibility of the South Carolina Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR, in assessing the legal duty of an attorney in a malpractice action.Â  Smith v. Haynsworth, Marion, McKay & Geurard,322 S.C. 433, 472 S.E.2d 612, 613 (1996).Â  Adopting the position of the Georgia Supreme Court, the Smith court declared:

This is not to say, however, that all of the Bar Rules would necessarily be relevant in every legal malpractice action. Â In order to relate to the standard of care in a particular case, we hold that a Bar Rule must be intended to protect a person in the plaintiffâ€™s position or be addressed to the particular harm. 

Id. at 437, 472 S.E.2d at 613 (quoting Allen v. Lefkoff, Duncan, Grimes & Dermer, 453 S.E.2d 719, 721-22 (Ga. 1995)).Â  Failure to comply with the Rules of Professional Conduct is not negligence per se, but merely one circumstance that may be considered along with other facts and circumstances in determining whether an attorney acted with reasonable care.Â  Id. at 437 n. 6, 472 S.E.2d at 613 n. 6. Â Additionally, this court has found the Rules of Professional Conduct relevant in deciding what constitutes reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees. Â See Weatherford v. Price, 340 S.C. 572, 581, 532 S.E.2d 310, 315 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œWe, therefore, conclude that our supreme court has not ruled that a fee agreement which violates Rule 1.5, RPC, is unenforceable in all circumstances as against public policy.Â  This does not mean, however, that the Rules of Professional Conduct have no
bearing on the issue.â€)
The applicable part of Rule 1.15 provides:

(d) Upon receiving funds or other property in which a client or third person has an interest, a lawyer shall promptly notify the client or third person. Â Except as stated in this rule or otherwise permitted by law or by agreement with the client, a lawyer shall promptly deliver to the client or third person any funds or other property that the client or third person is entitled to receive . . . .
(e) When in the course of representation a lawyer is in possession of property in which two or more persons (one of whom may be the lawyer) claim interests, the property shall be kept separate by the lawyer until the dispute is resolved. Â The lawyer shall promptly distribute all portions of the property as to which the interests are not in dispute.

Rule 1.15, RPC, Rule 407, SCACR.Â  The comments provide the following clarification:

Paragraph (e) also recognizes that third parties may have lawful claims against specific funds or other property in a lawyerâ€™s custody, such as a clientâ€™s creditor who has a lien on funds recovered in a personal injury action. Â A lawyer may have a duty under applicable law to protect such third-party claims against wrongful interference by the client. Â In such cases, when the third-party claim is not frivolous under applicable law, the lawyer must refuse to surrender the property to the client until the claims are resolved. Â A lawyer should not unilaterally assume to arbitrate a dispute between the client and the third party, but, when there are substantial grounds for dispute as to the person entitled to the funds, the lawyer may file an action to have a court resolve the dispute.

Rule 1.15, RPC, Rule 407, SCACR, cmt. 4.
Moore offered the opinion of licensed South Carolina attorney Mark Hardee as to the nature of Weinbergâ€™s duty.Â  In his affidavit, Hardee advised that â€œ[a]n attorney on notice of an escrow assignment has a duty to that person.â€Â  Hardee elaborated:

It is well settled under the ethics rules and South Carolina law that an attorney who has knowledge of an assignment cannot dishonor the assignment when disbursing funds if he has knowledge of the assignment.Â  This is true even if his client instructs him to dishonor the assignment and disburse the funds. . . .Â  Defendants had a duty to the Plaintiff to ensure that assignment was paid or that proper notice was given to the Plaintiff providing him the opportunity to protect his interests.Â  Their failure to do either was a breach of that duty. 

Weinberg drafted the Assignment and does not dispute that he had notice of it.Â  He contends he either forgot it or overlooked it.Â  The Rules of Professional Conduct specifically address this particular injury.Â  Moore was a third party entitled to funds in an attorneyâ€™s possession.Â  Guided by the Rules of Professional Conduct and inculcated by precedent established in other jurisdictions, we conclude Weinberg owed Moore a duty to disburse the assigned funds to Moore.Â  
Weinberg cited a Wisconsin Supreme Court case, Yorgan v. Durkin, 715 N.W.2d 160, 165 (Wis. 2006), in advancing his proposition that without a letter of protection, an attorney is not bound to a third party.Â  A letter of protection is a document by an attorney notifying a creditor that payment will be made when the case is settled or judgment is obtained.Â  Id. at 163.Â  In some circumstances, an attorney may agree to be contractually bound by proffering a letter of protection.Â  Id. at 165.Â  Such letters are â€œa common practice by which attorneys representing personal injury plaintiffs ensure their clients will receive necessary medical treatment, even if unable to pay until the case is concluded.â€Â  Id.Â  Weinberg contends Morganâ€™s cause of action fails without a letter of protection binding Weinberg.Â  
Â The facts in Yorgan are distinguishable from facts in this case.Â  In Yorgan, the client signed a chiropractorâ€™s form â€œAuthorization and Doctorâ€™s Lienâ€ directing an attorney to pay the chiropractor and purporting to give the chiropractor a lien against any proceeds the client recovered on a personal injury claim.Â  Id. at 162.Â  The client subsequently retained his attorney, who neither acknowledged nor signed the agreement.Â  Id.Â  The chiropractor sought recovery under contract and equitable lien causes of action.Â  Id.Â  The Wisconsin court held the chiropractor could not enforce the purported lien against the attorney under a contract cause of action.Â  Nor was the chiropractor entitled to an equitable lien enforceable against the clientâ€™s attorney.Â  In its decision, the court reasoned:

[The chiropractor] should have known based on the plain language of the agreement that he might not be protected unless [the attorney] signed the agreement or took some other affirmative action.Â  [The chiropractor] was, or should have been, aware of the potential for harm that an unsigned agreement could create. Â At the same time, he had at least some ability to seek to ensure his protection by insisting on an attorneyâ€™s signature on the agreement or a letter of protection.

715 N.W.2d at 168.
A letter of protection offers one method protecting a creditorâ€™s interest. Â However, the absence of a letter of protection does not automatically relieve an attorney of a duty under an assignment.Â  Moncrief v. Donohoe, 892 So. 2d 379 (Ala. Civ. App. 2003) (reversing the grant of summary judgment to an attorney who failed to honor an assignment, noting the assigneeâ€™s theory of liability was based on a claimed assignment of the settlement proceeds and not the unsigned letter of protection).Â  Unlike the factual scenario in Yorgan, Weinberg drafted and executed the Assignment and acknowledged the validity of the Assignment in his testimony.Â  Moore had no reason to believe Wheelerâ€™s obligation was not secured by the Assignment.Â  In fact, both Moore and Wheeler indicated Moore would not have executed the $92,000 loan without the security the Assignment provided.Â  Weinbergâ€™s notice of the Assignment is undisputed.Â  Weinbergâ€™s duty to Moore arose out of his knowledge of the Assignment.Â  A letter of protection was not necessary to create that duty.Â Â  
We hold the trial court erred in granting summary judgment on the negligence cause of action and reverse and remand that cause of action for a trial.
B.Â  Conversion
Â â€œConversion is the unauthorized assumption and exercise of the right of ownership over goods or personal chattels belonging to another, to the alteration of the condition or the exclusion of the ownerâ€™s rights.â€ Â Hawkins v. City of Greenville, 358 S.C. 280, 297, 594 S.E.2d 557, 566 (Ct. App. 2004) (citing Crane v. Citicorp Natâ€™l Servs., Inc., 313 S.C. 70, 73, 437 S.E.2d 50, 52 (1993) (superseded by statute on other grounds)). Â Conversion is a wrongful act that emanates by either a wrongful taking or wrongful detention. Â Kirby v. Horne Motor Co., 295 S.C. 7, 366 S.E.2d 259 (Ct. App. 1988). Â â€œConversion may arise by some illegal use or misuse, or by illegal detention of anotherâ€™s personal property.â€ Â Regions Bank v. Schmauch, 354 S.C. 648, 667, 582 S.E.2d 432, 442 (Ct. App. 2003) (citing
Owens v. Andrews Bank & Trust Co., 265 S.C. 490, 496, 220 S.E.2d 116, 119 (1975); Castell v. Stephenson Fin. Co., 244 S.C. 45, 50-51, 135 S.E.2d 311, 313 (1964)). Â A plaintiff may prevail upon a claim for conversion by showing the unauthorized detention of property, after demand. Â Mackela v. Bentley, 365 S.C. 44, 614 S.E.2d 648 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  The plaintiff must show either title or right to possession of the property at the time of
conversion. Â Oxford Fin. Cos. v. Burgess, 303 S.C. 534, 402 S.E.2d 480 (1991). 
The Alabama Civil Court of Appeals considered facts similar to those in the instant case to determine whether an attorney committed the tort of conversion.Â  The court reasoned:

  The assignment of the judgment was a transfer of the money to be collected on it; it was an absolute and unconditional appropriation of it to the assignee. Â The money, when collected by the attorney, was the property of the assignee, and held for his use, and we can perceive no reason why he should not be allowed to maintain this action to recover it after demand made, notice of the assignment of the judgment, having previously been given. . . . Â [A]n attorney at law, is the agent of the party, and the principal may appropriate money in his hands to the use of another, after notice of which, if he pays it to the principal like any other agent, he will be responsible to the person to whom the fund really belongs, in an action for money had and received, founded on the implied promise.

Birmingham News Co. v. Chamblee & Harris, 617 So. 2d 689, 691 (Ala. Civ. App. 1993) (quoting Gayle & Saffold v. Benson, 3 Ala. 234, 235-36 (1841)).
When Weinberg received the funds transferred from Clarendon County Clerk of Court, a portion of the funds belonged to Moore under the Assignment.Â  Weinberg had notice of the Assignment because he drafted it.Â  John Land demanded, on Mooreâ€™s behalf, payment of the money Wheeler owed. Weinbergâ€™s disbursement of the funds to Wheeler instead of Moore raises material questions regarding the claim of conversion. Â The trial court erred in granting summary judgment on this issue. 
C.Â  Civil Conspiracy
The elements a plaintiff must demonstrate in order to prove civil
conspiracy include: (1) the combination of two or more people; (2) for the purpose of injuring the plaintiff; (3) causing special damages.Â  Pye v. Estate of Fox, 369 S.C. 555, 566-67, 633 S.E.2d 505, 511 (2006).Â  â€œIn order to establish a conspiracy, evidence, either direct or circumstantial, must be produced from which a party may reasonably infer the joint assent of the minds of two or more parties to the prosecution of the unlawful enterprise.â€ Â Cowburn v. Leventis, 366 S.C. 20, 49, 619 S.E.2d 437, 453 (Ct. App. 2005) (quoting First Union Natâ€™l Bank of S.C. v. Soden, 333 S.C. 554, 575, 511 S.E.2d 372, 383 (Ct. App. 1998)); see also Island Car Wash, Inc. v. Norris, 292 S.C. 595, 601, 358 S.E.2d 150, 153 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  Conspiracy may be inferred from the nature of the acts committed, the relationship of the parties, the interests of the alleged conspirators, and other relevant circumstances.Â 
Id.Â  Because civil conspiracy is â€œby its very nature covert and clandestine,â€ it is usually not provable by direct evidence. Â Id. Â 
â€œ[A]n attorney is [generally] immune from liability to third persons arising from the performance of his professional activities as an attorney on behalf of and with the knowledge of his client.â€ Â Pye, 369 S.C. at 564, 633 S.E.2d at 509 (quoting Gaar v. N. Myrtle Beach Realty Co., 287 S.C. 525, 528, 339 S.E.2d 887, 889 (Ct. App. 1986)).Â  However, the South Carolina Supreme Court cautions that â€œan attorney may be held liable for conspiracy where, in addition to representing his client, he breaches some independent duty to a third person . . . .â€ Â Id. at 564, 633 S.E.2d at 509-10 (quoting Stiles v. Onorato, 318 S.C. 297, 300, 457 S.E.2d 601, 602 (1995)).

 Our review of the record in Cowburn revealed no evidence of an agreement between the defendants or any indication they joined together for the purpose of injuring the plaintiff.Â  Accordingly, we held no genuine issue of material fact existed to establish a claim for civil conspiracy. Â 366 S.C. at 49, 619 S.E.2d at 453.Â  In this case, Moore provided no evidence that Weinberg and Wheeler colluded to deprive Moore of the funds he was entitled to under the Assignment. Â All the evidence contained in the record indicated Weinberg forgot about the Assignment.Â  No material question of fact exists as to the civil conspiracy cause of action.Â  Although the trial court erred in granting the summary judgment on the basis of novation, we may affirm the grant of summary judgment on any ground found in the record. Â See Rule 220(c), SCACR (â€œThe appellate court may affirm any ruling, order, decision or judgment upon any ground(s) appearing in the Record on Appeal.â€).Â  Because no material question of fact as to the civil conspiracy cause of action existed, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment solely as to that cause of action.
CONCLUSION
We hold novation is NOT a defense to causes of action sounding in tort.Â  We rule Weinberg owed a legal duty to Moore based on Weinbergâ€™s Â Â notice of the Assignment.Â  Consequently, the trial court erred in granting summary judgment on the negligence cause of action.Â  
Additionally, we determine because Moore had a valid Assignment to a portion of the escrow account, accompanied by Weinbergâ€™s notice of the Assignment, the trial court erred in granting summary judgment on the issue of conversion.Â  Finally, we conclude there is no material question of fact as to Mooreâ€™s civil conspiracy cause of action.Â  The trial court did not err in granting summary judgment on the civil conspiracy claim.Â  
Accordingly, the order of the trial court is
Affirmed in Part, Reversed in Part, and Remanded.
KITTREDGE and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]  Weinberg represented Wheeler on a contingency fee basis.Â  The fee agreement provided that Wheeler would pay Weinberg one-third of his recovery; they later renegotiated the fee to one-fourth of the recovery.
[3]  Land clarified in his letter that, though he represented Moore, he would not take a case against Weinberg due to their relationship.Â  Land emphasized he hoped the matter could be resolved without further action.

title: Hull v. Spartanburg County Assessor
description: This case uses of the income approach when valuing a lessed property for tax purposes.  Under the income approach, the tenant's financial difficulties are reflected in the capitalization rate.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
James M. Hull, Appellant,
v.
Spartanburg County Assessor, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
 G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4210
Submitted January 1, 2007 â€“ Filed February 20, 2007

AFFIRMED 


  
    
      
Timothy E. Madden, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Edwin C. Haskell, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

CURETON, A.J.:  James M. Hull appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order affirming the Administrative Law Judgeâ€™s (ALJ) order valuing Hullâ€™s property for the 2002 tax year. Hull contends the ALJ erred in failing to take into account the lesseeâ€™s, K-Martâ€™s, financial difficulties and the special purpose of the building in determining the value of the property.  We affirm.
FACTS
This appeal arises from a dispute regarding the 2002 tax valuation of the land and buildings located on Spartanburg County, Tax Parcel 6-20-08-004.01.  The owner of the leasehold estate for the property is H/S Super Spartanburg, L.P., which is represented by its president and general partner, Hull.Â  Hull owns fifty percent of H.S. Super Spartanburg, L.P.  Located on this property of approximately 21.7 acres is a special purpose 171,245 square-foot building, built in 1994, which is leased by K-Mart.  A special purpose building of this type is referred to as a â€œbig box.â€ 
The date that controlled the tax valuation for 2002 (tax control date) was December 31, 2001.  The tax assessor valued the property at $12,343,400.  Hull appealed the valuation to the ALJ. 
The tax assessor testified he considered the physical location and the economic and financial characteristics surrounding the property.  The tax assessor found the building was of good quality and very well located near an interstate, shopping mall, and many prime national tenants, such as Loweâ€™s, Samâ€™s, Circuit City, and Best Buy.    
The tax assessor used the three standard approaches in valuing properties of this nature: cost approach, direct sales comparison approach, and income approach.  According to the tax assessor the income approach â€œis of the utmost importance because buyers and sellers in essence buy such investment properties based on the income generating capacity of such properties.â€  Utilizing the income approach, the tax assessor arrived at a value of $13,500,000 after considering the propertyâ€™s rent of $7.87 per square foot, which results in a yearly rent of $1,200,000, and then capitalizing the rental income.   
Under the direct sales comparison approach, the tax assessor testified similar properties were selling from the high $50 to $80 per square foot on the tax control date.  These findings led the tax assessor to value the property between $12,000,000 and $13,000,000 under the direct sales comparison approach.  The tax assessor further emphasized the superiority of the income approach because on the tax control date, K-Mart was operating its business and paying rent according to its lease agreement.  After using all three approaches, the assessor arrived at a valuation range of $12,000,000 to $13,500,000 and assessed the property at $12,343,400.  
On the other hand, Hullâ€™s expert appraiser, Ashby Krouse, testified that the raw land was the only valuable aspect of the property.  Krouse valued the property at $4,889,250.  Krouseâ€™s valuation considered the history, anticipated actions by K-Mart, and credit worthiness of K-Mart.  Krouse testified that on the tax control date, it was widely known that K-Mart was in financial trouble and that its stock had fallen to five dollars per share.  K-Mart did not make its January 1, 2002 lease payment on this property, but was current in its lease payments on December 31, 2001.  K-Mart filed Chapter 11 Bankruptcy on January 22, 2002.  Not all K-Mart stores were closed.  Hull testified K-Mart rejected its lease with Hull in February 2003. Â  
At trial, the appropriate capitalization rate was heavily debated.  Krouse explained â€œthe net income from that property is capitalized by the capitalization rate to come up with a value of the subject property.â€  Wal-Mart, a similar competitor, has a capitalization rate of approximately 8.5 to 9%, which according to Krouse, is indicative of Wal-Martâ€™s high credit worthiness.  A low capitalization rate results in a high value.  Hull prepared his own appraisals of the property and included a 10% and 12.5% capitalization rate in his appraisals.  At trial, Hull testified he believed 13.5% would be a more appropriate rate, but insisted the property was only worth the value of the land. 
The ALJ valued the property for the 2002 tax year at $10,215,000 based on a capitalization rate of 12.5%.  The ALJ concluded that the 9% capitalization rate suggested by the tax assessor was inappropriate because the suggestions of bankruptcy and the drop in the price of K-Mart shares would cause a potential buyer, cognizant of the risk, to seek a higher return than the 9% assigned to the relatively stable competitor, Wal-Mart. 
The ALJâ€™s order was appealed to the circuit court.  The circuit court affirmed the ALJâ€™s order finding that there was ample evidence in the record to support the ALJâ€™s conclusion that K-Mart was solvent on the tax control date and in compliance with its lease obligations on the property.  The ALJ accepted the tax assessorâ€™s evaluation with the exception of applying a 12.5% capitalization rate. The circuit court concluded the ALJâ€™s findings were supported by substantial evidence in the record.  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The review of an ALJâ€™s order is confined to the record.  See South Carolina Code Â§1-23-610(C) (2005).  â€œThe findings of the agency are presumed correct and will be set aside only if unsupported by substantial evidence.â€  Kearse v. State Health and Human Servs. Fin. Commâ€™n, 318 S.C. 198, 200, 456 S.E.2d 892, 893 (1995) (citation omitted).  â€œâ€˜Substantial evidenceâ€™ is not a mere scintilla of evidence nor the evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the administrative agency reached or must have reached in order to justify its action.â€  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 135, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Property Valuation Regarding K-Martâ€™s Financial Difficulties 
 Hull argues the ALJ erred by failing to fully consider K-Martâ€™s financial difficulties in his property valuation.  We disagree.
 Section 12-37-930 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) requires:

All property must be valued for taxation at its true value in money which in all cases is the price which the property would bring following reasonable exposure to the market, where both the seller and the buyer are willing, are not acting under compulsion, and are reasonably well informed of the uses and purposes for which it is adapted and for which it is capable of being used.

â€œAt least four methods exist for determining fair market
value of property for taxation purposes: analysis of comparable sales, capitalization of gross income, capitalization of net income, and reproduction cost less depreciation and obsolescence.â€  72 Am. Jur. 2d State and Local Taxation Â§ 669 (2001). 
Under the income approach, the appraiser determines the net rental income the property will generate and then capitalizes the income at a rate a land purchaser would expect to obtain from the property. 
Id.  Furthermore, the net income figure must reflect the appraiserâ€™s estimate of the propertyâ€™s earning potential, because the income approach â€œis based on the fundamental notion that the market value of income-producing property reflects the present worth of the future income stream.â€ 
Id.
In the case at hand, the record reflects that the tax assessor used the cost approach, direct sales comparison approach, and the income approach in valuating the property.  The tax assessor capitalized the projected rent of over $1,200,000 at an approximate rate of 9% and reached a figure of about $13,500,000 under the income approach.  The record also reflects testimony from Hull that 13.5% would be a more appropriate capitalization rate, which would result in a value of $6,778,343 for the property.  The record contains appraisals created by Hull for the property using capitalization rates of 10% and 12.5%.  Conversely, Hullâ€™s expert, Krouse, testified that the propertyâ€™s value was only $4,889,250, the value of the land.  
The income approach is a recognized method for valuing property, specifically when the propertyâ€™s value is largely based on rental income. See S.C. Tax Commâ€™n v. South Carolina Tax Bd. of Review, 287 S.C. 415, 339 S.E.2d 131 (Ct. App. 1985). The ALJ properly applied the income approach by identifying the annual gross income as $1,347,275 and subtracting expenses to reach a net annual income of $1,276,822.  The ALJ then capitalized the net income rate by 12.5%.  The ALJ accounted for K-Martâ€™s financial difficulties on the tax control date by utilizing a capitalization rate within the range of testimony, consistent with the evidence, and reflective of K-Martâ€™s financial situation on the tax control date.  Therefore, the record supports the ALJâ€™s utilization of the income approach to determine the fair market value and the use of a 12.5% capitalization rate.
The ALJâ€™s valuation was additionally supported by comparable rents in the area.Â  The tax assessor testified the property in question rents for about $7.87 per square foot and the market rent for the neighborhood is approximately $7 per square foot.  The tax assessor explained the amounts differ because the location of this property is prime.  Hull also testified that the property was in â€œthe best location in the community.â€  The property is near an interstate, a shopping mall, and other national stores.  Therefore, the difference of $0.87 per square foot in the rent value used by the tax assessor and the marketâ€™s rental value is supported in view of the propertyâ€™s superior location.
II.  Deed Restrictions 
Lastly, Hull argues the special purpose of the building is tantamount to a deed restriction restricting the building to use by K-Mart, which would affect the value of the property.  We disagree.
In Long Cove Home Ownersâ€™ Assâ€™n, Inc. v. Beaufort County Tax Equalization Bd., 327 S.C. 135, 141, 488 S.E.2d 857, 861 (1997), the court interpreted section 12-37-930 to say that, â€œregardless of [the] method used to determine true value, deed restrictions affecting the use of the land must be considered when determining value.â€  Before the ALJ, Krouse testified that a special purpose, big box building like this K-Mart store could not be adapted for a similar, new tenant.  He insisted the building would instead need to be torn down and the land made suitable for a new, big box store.  If the landlord chose not to tear down the building, Krouse testified an option would be to use the building as a flea market.  Hull estimated that a lease for a flea market would earn between $2 and $3 per square foot, significantly less than the current $7.87 per square foot K-Mart lease rental for the property.
Despite the difficulty in adapting the property for a subsequent big box retailer, on the tax control date, K-Mart was not in default on its lease.  On the tax control date, the special purpose property was fulfilling its intended purpose of housing a K-Mart store.  K-Mart did not reject its lease until February 2003.  The ALJ accounted for concerns about K-Martâ€™s financial status in arriving at the proper capitalization rate.  Therefore, on the tax control date the difficulty of adapting the big box building was not a factor because K-Mart was utilizing the special purpose building for the purpose indicated in its lease.  Additionally, speculation regarding the continuation of K-Martâ€™s use of the building was considered by the ALJ.
CONCLUSION
The property valuation by the ALJ considered the financial difficulties of K-Mart on the tax control date and substantial evidence supports the valuation.  The special purpose building was being utilized for its intended purpose on the tax control date; therefore, the uniqueness of the building did not act as a deed restriction.  Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s order affirming the ALJâ€™s decision is 
 AFFIRMED.      
HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

description: The S.C. Court of Appeals affirmed the circuit court's decision to admit evidence gathered from a show-up identification. text:
Cornelius Govan appeals his armed robbery conviction


  THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
  The State, Respondent,
  v.
  Cornelius Govan, Appellant.
      
    
  


  Appeal From Beaufort County
  Â Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge

  Opinion No. 4211
  Heard January 9, 2007 â€“ Filed February 26, 2007Â Â 

  AFFIRMED


  
    
      
  Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, for Appellant
  Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney Salley W. Elliott, Senior AssistantÂ  Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and Solicitor I. McDuffie Stone, III, of Beaufort, for Respondent.
      
    
  

  SHORT, J.:Â  Cornelius Govan appeals his armed robbery conviction.Â  He argues the trial court erred in denying his motions to suppress both his show-up identification as unduly suggestive and unreliable and the resulting in-court identification as tainted by the prior suggestive show-up.Â  We affirm. 
  FACTS
  On December 29, 2004, the House of Tang Restaurant (Restaurant) was robbed at gunpoint.Â  The owner of the Restaurant, Yin Lin, stated that a â€œblack guyâ€ in a long black jacket and black hat (or rag) entered the Restaurant, held a gun â€œin my hair,â€ and demanded money from the cash register.Â  Lin put the money from the register into a bag, and the robber fled on a bicycle with one thousand twenty-four dollars.Â  Â 
  Yu Chen, a second Restaurant employee, was eating with Lin at the time of the robbery.Â  Chen corroborated the information provided by Lin.Â  When the robber fled on a bicycle, Chen ran outside and followed him in Linâ€™s car.Â  While following the robber, Chen hit the bicycle with the car, and then both the robber and Chen left the scene on foot.Â Â
